Description: A proof-of-concept (PoC) grant is a competency-based research funding instrument for experimental development in order to test and/or create conditions for the commercialization of research outcomes.
Objective(s): enhancing technology transfer, the application of research outcomes in enterprises and in society.|strengthening the societal and economic impact of research.
Background:
A proof-of-concept (PoC) grant is a new competency-based research funding instrument for experimental development in order to test and/or create conditions for the commercialization of research outcomes. Prerequisite for applying proof-of-concept grant is the previous research of the applicant, in which technology readiness level at least 4 has been achieved. A proof-of-concept grant is awarded for the implementation of an independent research project at an Estonian R&D institution, which has been regularly positively evaluated in at least one research field, and its purpose is not funding other self-financed research projects. A proof-of-concept grant contains costs directly related to the implementation of the project and overhead costs. The grant period of a proof-of-concept grant is up to one year. The application process has 2 stages.
Proof-of-concept grant is established to fill the gap between applied research and application of research outcomes in enterprises and in society. The experimental development grant is aimed at those researchers who are interested in applying / applying their research results in business. Because of the high risks involved in this activity, neither scientists nor entrepreneurs are interested in taking these risks without testing resources.

English name: BRICS SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY AND INNOVATION WORK PLAN
Description: This Work Plan is organized in four main tracks of cooperation: (i) Research Collaboration, (ii) Research Infrastructure, (iii) Innovation Collaboration and (iv) Sustainability (long-term cooperation).
Objective(s): The BRICS STI research collaboration is comprised of two main initiatives: the STI thematic working groups and the joint calls for research projects. In the thematic working groups, officials and researchers define lines of action; develop joint projects; exchange knowledge and experience in their areas of study; and decide the scope of the joint calls. The nine working groups in this category are: (i) Prevention and Monitoring of Natural disasters; (ii) New and renewable energy, and energy efficiency (with a sub-group on Solid State Lightning – SSL); (iii) Material Sciences and Nanotechnology; (iv) Information and Communication Technologies and High Performance Computing; (v) Astronomy; (vi) Biotechnology and Biomedicine, including human health and neuroscience; (vii) Ocean and polar science and technology; (viii) Geospatial technologies and its applications; (ix) Photonics.|The BRICS Research Infrastructure (RI) collaboration is developed through the BRICS GRAIN Platform, which provides information and the list of available research opportunities for scientists. Furthermore, its key objectives include: i. Single entry point for potential Research Infrastructure Users and Partners: RI objects info, access/partnership policy, contacts; ii. Integrated source of BRICS RI people contacts, events as well as working proceedings regarding integrating, policy developing, communication initiatives, RI projects; iii. Up to date info for BRICS STI Senior Officials regarding BRICS RI WG progress.|The activities for the 2019 - 2022 period of the BRICS Innovation Collaboration shall emphasize the proposal on STI-led innovation cooperation among BRICS countries announced at the 4th BRICS STI Ministerial Meeting in India (2016), and the implementation of the BRICS Action Plan on Innovation Cooperation 2017-2020, adopted by the 9th BRICS Summit (China, 2017).|BRICS Governments should seek ways to make it sustainable long-term cooperation. That means they must create opportunities for scientific communities and enterprises strengthening their interactions and achieving joint concrete results, regardless of the direct involvement of the governments officials. It also means they should foster initiatives whose results can be felt during a long period of time.
Background: The Ministers and their representatives for Science, Technology and Innovation of the Federative Republic of Brazil, the Russian Federation, the Republic of India, the People’s Republic of China and the Republic of South Africa, met in Campinas, on 20 September 2019 for the 7th BRICS Science, Technology and Innovation Ministerial Meeting and endorsed the BRICS Science, Technology and Innovation Work Plan 2019-2022 as a part of Campinas Declaration. This Work Plan enumerates the cooperation activities to be developed in this four-year period, in accordance to the BRICS Memorandum of Understanding on Cooperation in Science, Technology and Innovation, signed in Brasília, in 2015.

English name: The Project-based System for Funding Government R&D Program
Description: Along with institutional funding for government research institutes (GRIs), a project-based system (PBS) was introduced to promote competitive funding and problem-solving research. Currently, the ratios of PBS in GRIs are between 30~60%.
Objective(s): To promote competitive funding to government research institutes|To promote problem-solving research in GRIs
Background:
Although PBS system has motivated competitive and problem-solving research in government research institutes (GRIs) to a significant extent, the PBS system has produced a number of challenges including boosting short-sighted research, weakening basic long-term research, hindering disruptive innovation, etc.
Responding to such challenges, a new policy direction is set to reduce the portion of competitive funding through PBS and to increase institutional funding to GRIs by asking GRIs to submit their own Roles and Responsibility and identify their clear role.

Description: The Research Infrastructure Roadmap is a long-term (10-20 years) planning instrument which will be updated regularly (at an interval of 3 years). In 2018, the previous Roadmap was updated and the updated version was approved by Government Order No 43 from 14th of February 2019 as Supplement to the Implementation Plan for the Estonian Research, Development and Innovation Strategy 2014-2020 “Knowledge-based Estonia”.
Objective(s): The Estonian Roadmap for Research Infrastructures is a strategic initiative for planning and developing research infrastructures. The 2019 Roadmap lists 14 planned and 3 implemented research infrastructures of national importance. It includes also list of 14 Estonian participations in international research infrastructure organisations.
Background: The first Estonian Research Infrastructure Roadmap has been prepared at the end of 2009 as a joint initiative of the Ministry of Education and Research and the Academy of Science. The Roadmap was approved by the Government in 2010. The second version of the Roadmap was prepared by the Estonian Research Council and the Ministry of Education and Research in 2014 and includes 18 objects. The third version of the national Research Infrastructure Roadmap was published in 2019. Being included to the Roadmap does not give to a research infrastructure automatic funding. All research infrastructures listed in the Roadmap are eliglible to apply for national financial support. Estonia uses EU Structural Funds to support the construction of Roadmap objects. The the first call for funding of research infrastructures and decisions of inclusion to the plan of investments were finished in the first half of 2016. The second call was issued in 2019. The Roadmap includes also infrastructures that intend to develop academic e-infrastructure and digitaal infrastructures for the dissemination of research data. The Natural History Archives and Information Network (NATARC) develops the structure of repositories and provides services and value tools for digital natural history collections. The Estonian e-Repository and Conservation of Collections (E-varamu) aims to improve the capabilities of University libraries in preserving and digitising research information, and to develop a search portal for accessing scientific information. The Estonian Centre for Genomics is in charge of developing IT infrastructure for the Estonian National Gene Bank.

BELLA will achieve this through the procurement of a long-term Indefeasible Right of Use (IRU) for spectrum on a submarine cable between the two regions, minimising latency. BELLA is also developing and deploying a 100Gbps-capable research and education network across Latin America.
Objective(s): The Project aims to promote the integration of Latin American and European research and innovation networks through a direct submarine fiber optic connection between both continents. The initiative also aims to expand the capacity of terrestrial connectivity within Latin America.
Responsible organisation(s): RNP (RNP;Rede Nacional de Ensino e Pesquisa)

Description: The Amazon Tall Tower Observatory (ATTO) is a research site in the Amazon rainforest in Brazil in cooperation with Germany. On its center is a 325 m-tall steel guyed mast. In addition, it includes two further 80 m tall towers, as well as several container-laboratories and a base camp to accommodate scientists and technicians working there. Nearby field sites and study plots complete the site.
Objective(s): Its aim is to continuously record meteorological, chemical and biological data, such as the concentration of greenhouses gases. With the help of these data, the goal is to learn more about biogeochemical cycles (such as the carbon cycle), the water cycle and energy fluxes in the Amazon. We want to determine their impact on global climate and how they are influenced by the changing climate.

Description: The Amazon Mission will provide remote sensing data (images) to observe and monitor deforestation, especially in the Amazon region, as well as the diversified agriculture throughout the country with a high revisit rate, working in synergy with existing environmental programs.
Objective(s): The data will be available to both the scientific community and government agencies and to users interested in a better understanding of the terrestrial environment. In Addition, the mission has an important technological objective: the validation of the PMM Multi Mission Platform as a system, which will be used for the first time in the Amazonia-1 satellite.
Background: Since the 1990s, Brazil has been attempting to launch a fully designed, integrated, tested and operated Earth Observation satellite. Satellite has been successfully lauched in 2021.

Description: Building capacity and capability in the UK supporting research and translation in sustainable, biologically based manufacturing through collaboration between academic researchers and businesses at all levels.
Objective(s): Drive new ideas to harness the potential of biological resources for producing and processing materials, biopharmaceuticals, chemicals and energy.
Background: The first iteration of the Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Resource Council (BBSRC) Networks in Industrial Biotechnology and Bioenergy (NIBBs) ran from 2013 - 2019. The first phase NIBBs supported 13 different networks, covering biorefining, bioprocessing, biocatalysis and high value chemicals. They have resulted in a robust community of academic and business members with a pipeline of projects at various stages of translation that will deliver key benefits across the bioeconomy. Phase II of the NIBBs rationalised the 13 original networks into 6 new ones, covering algae, biomass biorefining, carbon recycling, metals in biology, environmental biotechnology and high value biorenewables.

English name: Grants for establishing Centres of Excellence
Description: Research carried out in the previous period in Montenegro in certain domains has achieved solid international recognition in terms of quality. The intention behind creating new centres of excellence is to use the financing period to create conditions for a significant increase in research activity and its further intensification in the promising areas for Montenegro, defined by the Strategy of Scientific Research Activity and the Smart Specialisation Strategy, as well as by other national and local policies and plans.
Objective(s): Creating or significantly improving products or services for a precisely defined economic branch, which can help existing companies in Montenegro to improve their international competitiveness by integrating advanced scientific concepts, technologies and innovations into traditional economic sectors.|Creating a research base for a priority state or local policy that would provide the public sector with the knowledge and specific services needed in the transformation of society (e.g. digital society, energy efficient cities, ecological Montenegro, etc.), and contribute to the creation of future markets for innovative services and products.|Creating a scientific research area in Montenegro that has the potential for exceptional results on the global level, which would provide a competitive advantage to the national economy and a better position of Montenegrin science on the global stage, leading also to the possibility of exponential growth in science and innovation.
Background:
The scientific research activity in Montenegro is mainly exercised in the higher education sector, i.e. at Montenegrin universities. Staff employed in research and development activities usually perform this activity as part of their regular working hours, predominantly dedicated to teaching activities. Research, development and innovation in the economic sector are not at a satisfactory level and only a few economic entities are recognised in the scientific research and innovation system. Such a research and development organisation results in research of small intensity and scope at the state level, which must be enhanced by new elements of the system focused on scientific research work.

Centres of excellence should bring together the best researchers and experts, focusing on full-scale research with a special emphasis on strategically defined areas, and thus directing the country’s science and economy to dynamic development. By the end of 2018, the Government of Montenegro will adopt the Smart Specialisation Strategy, and it is expected that the centres of excellence will present one of the instruments for its implementation. The centres of excellence should utilise international collaborations, as well as collaboration between different sectors and research disciplines, which helps overcome the shortcomings of individual organisations and enable faster integration and transfer of knowledge and technology.

The Strategy of Scientific Research Activities (2017-2021) and the Strategy of Innovation Activities (2016-2020) envisage a number of measures that are being implemented, in order to enable the impact of the research and innovation system on society as a whole, as well as to facilitate better internal and international integration and to provide attractive environment for research work. It is also necessary for scientific research institutions, especially those in higher education, to adapt to stronger research activities. The institutions hosting centres of excellence, primarily universities, are expected to adapt their rules of internal work and organisation, providing conditions for attracting exceptional researchers, concluding business contracts with the economy and other stakeholders in society, as well as for work on international projects, so that centres of excellence could achieve the desired dynamism.

Taking into account the fact that there are nuclei of scientific excellence in Montenegro and given the provisions of the Law on Scientific Research Activities and the 2017-2021 Strategy of Scientific Research Activities (Objective 5.1 – Human Resources and Research Capacities Development; Measure 5.1.2 – Encouraging Excellence and Networking; Activity 5.1.2.2 – Encouraging the Creation of Centres of Excellence), the intention of the universities to further develop research, entrepreneurial and broader social mission, as well as the strategic orientation of the economy towards innovation at this stage of development, the Government of Montenegro has included in its Priorities Programme the objective of establishing new centres of excellence that would be the driving force of scientific activity and the core of development and innovation activities in the country in the promising areas for Montenegro.

English name: Programme for implementation of Open Science principles in Montenegro
Description: In 2020 the Ministry of Science adopted a Programme for implementation of Open Science principles in Montenegro with the Action Plan (2020-2022).
Objective(s): Harmonization and implementation of the "Open Science" principles with the EU Open Science Action Plan
Background:
Since 2018, the Ministry of Science has been co-financing the publication of Montenegrin research papers in Open Access journals, i.e. covering APC for papers accepted for publication in Q1-Q2 journals, within their relevant fields – which is one of the first practical measures taken in terms of the Open Access, which has been implemented.

Furthermore, in 2020 the Programme for implementation of Open Science principles in Montenegro with the Action Plan (2020-2022) was adopted. The Programme draws upon several national strategic documents aimed at enhancing the scientific and research environment and strengthening the innovation ecosystem and its implementation will enable Montenegro to significantly harmonize the implementation of the “Open Science” principles with the EU Open Science Action Plan, taking into account that it follows the European Commission recommendations for this field. The focus will be on three Open Science dimensions, namely: open access to scientific publications, open research data, and open research infrastructures.

Montenegro is part of the European Open Cloud initiative, i.e. as a country associated to H2020 framework programme, they have an appointed delegate at the EOSC Governance Board.
Also, Montenegro is participating in regular EU member states’ meetings of the network of National Points of Reference on access and preservation of scientific information.

The Programme for implementation of Open Science principles in Montenegro (2020-2022) envisages open access to publications, research data and research infrastructures as key elements for improving the development of research and innovation and networking with potential stakeholders from the academic, business, public and civil sectors.

The Programme implementation implies specific steps, both at national and institutional level, i.e.:
▪ Improving the legislative framework to better reflect the application of Open Science principles;
▪ Establishing national Open Science infrastructures, i.e. national repositories for storing publications and data resulting from publicly funded research, as well as registries with information on scientific research infrastructure and scientific research institutions in which they are accessed and services offered and how to access them;
▪ Enhancing the application of Open Science principles to improve the excellence and relevance of scientific research activities;
▪ Developing human capital through education and promotion of the Open Science principles to strengthen competitiveness in the field of research.
Furthermore, the Ministry provides incentives i.e. co-financing of publication of papers by Montenegrin scientists in open access journals.

English name: South East European International Institute for Sustainable Technologies
Description: SEEIIST is a regional initiative led by Montenegro to create a regional research infrastructure
Objective(s): Science for Peace|Scientific Excellence|International Collaboration|Sustainable development of society|Education|Technology Transfer, Development of powerful digital network and high performance computing and Big Data handling
Background:
The South East European International Institute for Sustainable Technologies (SEEIIST) proposed in late 2016 by Prof. Herwig Schopper, a former Director General of CERN and initiator of the international SESAME project in Jordan, received first official political support by the Government of Montenegro in March 2017.

After the signing of the Declaration of Intent in October 2017 at CERN, the Initiative was transformed into a Regional project gathering following Parties: Republic of Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Republic of Bulgaria, Kosovo*, Republic of North Macedonia, Montenegro, Republic of Serbia and Republic of Slovenia.
Initially, there were two project options: a ‘4th Generation Synchrotron Light Source’ that would offer a broad spectrum of research and industrial applications, and a state-of-the-art ‘Facility for Hadron Tumour Therapy and Biomedical Research with protons and heavier ions’. Concept Studies behind each proposal were worked out by the two groups of the international experts.

At the second SEEIIST SC meeting, held on 30 March 2018 in Tirana (Republic of Albania), SC members took an unanimous decision to support the Hadron Cancer Therapy and Biomedical Research with Protons and Heavy Ions as the option for the Institute. Moreover, SC reached an agreement on a Draft of the Memorandum of Cooperation (MoC).

South East European International Institute for Sustainable Technologies - Montenegro has had a leadership role in the creation of a new large-scale regional research infrastructure, i.e. the project of establishing the International Institute for Sustainable Technologies in Southeast Europe (SEEIIST) – “Hadron Cancer Therapy and Research in the field of biomedicine using protons and heavy ions”. SEEIIST will offer research capacity to about 1000 researchers from and outside the SEE region. These researchers will become users of the SEEIIST, pursuing innovation in particle therapy and jointly advancing current knowledge.

Background:

different stages of the Strategy development – more precisely from identification of the challenges and priorities to formulation of the final text.

The strategy is based on clear identification of the main challenges of Education sector, thus ensuring its relevance through careful definition of the priority areas to be addressed within the period till 2025. At the same time, in order to meet the criteria of credibility, only the measures that can be implemented within
the planned period are included in the Strategy and supported by a costed Action Plan with identified sources of funding. However, the strategy suggests also longer term objectives which may be considered while programming the next phases of education development in the country.
The document firstly covers six main pillars of education system – Pre-school Education; Primary Education; Secondary Education; Vocational Education and Training; Higher Education and Research; and Adult Learning and Education. Background:
BMVI - as the AI application ministry – promotes, among others, AI innovations for new forms of mobility, for automated and connected driving as well as through the data-based funding program mFUND. In order to actively support the development of AI-driven mobility, BMVI also plans to establish AI centers for mobility in Germany, which will provide optimal networking for all participants, inspire and facilitate the application of AI in the mobility sector and the rapid transfer from research to practice, and thus strengthening competitiveness in this field.

-Expansion of a high-performance, digital infrastructure
-Equipping transport infrastructure with the necessary digital technology

-Networking of measures and actors across all modes of transport

English name: THE 11TH DEVELOPMENT PLAN OF TURKEY- AI TECHNOLOGIES
Description: Published by the Presidency of the Republic of Turkey, the Development Plan aims to transform Turkey’s economic structure and improve the welfare of its people, including through breakthroughs in technology and innovation.
Objective(s): To improve the capacity to produce and use knowledge by establishing an efficiently functioning research and innovation ecosystem.|To increase R&D and innovation activities that would support high value-added products and services.
Background:
The plan includes a number of measures specific to AI and as well as its overarching objectives related to inclusive growth, creating nationwide awareness and coordination on science, technology and innovation and employs a range of policy instruments.

The policies and measures related to specifically AI include:
• Preparing a roadmap for national-scale studies aimed at the development of domestic technology production capabilities and roll out of these technologies across the whole economy, in the field of AI technologies.
• Establishing an educational data bank where databases related to the education system are integrated and the data will be processed by AI technologies.
• Improving processes and technological infrastructure in order to utilise new technologies such as big data, cloud computing, mobile platforms, internet of things, AI and blockchain in the development of public services.
• Encouraging technology suppliers to develop applications and services that can be offered on the industrial cloud platform such as AI, advanced data analytics, simulation and optimisation, product lifecycle and production management systems. The use of this platform by companies will be encouraged through support for digital transformation.
• Preparing road maps for AI, internet of things, augmented reality, big data, cybersecurity, energy storage, advanced material, robotics, micro/nano/optoelectronics, biotechnology, quantum, sensor technologies and additive manufacturing technologies. These will address infrastructure, human capital and social considerations.
• Developing agricultural information systems with digitalisation, AI and data-based business models and making them widely available.
Responsible organisation(s): Presidency of Strategy and Budget (SBB;Cumhurbaşkanlığı Strateji ve Bütçe Başkanlığı)

Theme(s): Research infrastructures

Target group(s): Civil society|National government

English name: HUMAN-CENTERED NATIONAL GUIDELINES FOR AI ETHICS
Description: Ethical standards for AI for the development and use of trustworthy artificial intelligence.
Objective(s): Build a foundation for social deliberation and discussion to establish artificial intelligence ethics.|Secure social trust in artificial intelligence technology.
Background:
The ‘National Strategy for Artificial Intelligence’ established in 2019 stipulates ‘Preparation of AI code of ethics, and development and dissemination of ethics education curriculum’. This guideline is to set the ethical standards of artificial intelligence at the government level for the implementation of the national AI strategy.
Artificial intelligence technology is expected to improve the quality of life of the people through new innovative products and services as well as enhancing productivity in the industry as a whole. However, it also has potential risk factors such as data bias, discrimination by algorithms, and a breach of privacy during the development and utilization process. The establishment of ethics in the field of artificial intelligence will contribute to the promotion of the artificial intelligence industry in the growing stage by securing social trust in artificial intelligence technology.

Description: The National Basic Research Programme aims to develop basic research, innovation and technologies in line with national targets for economic and social development.

Background: The Knowledge Innovation Programme (KIP) was inaugurated by the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) in 1998. When the programme was initiated CAS supported more than 100 institutes many of which had overlapping missions and outdated agendas or needed staff renewals and infrastructure upgrade. The KIP programme was intended to address these issues by rationalizing resources allocation and improving overall competitiveness of CAS research institutes. In 2010 CAS launched Innovation 2020, an extension of the KIP programme, which lays special emphasis on four key areas, namely space science, information technology, energy and health.

Description: The Polish Roadmap for Research Infrastructures is a strategic document to guide the development of future research initiatives of a national and international scale.
Objective(s): The purpose of the Polish Roadmap for Research Infrastructures is to guide the development of future research infrastructure initiatives of a national and international scale in a long-term. At the same time, it corresponds to the European approach of linking national research strategies with the European ones under the auspices of the European Strategy Forum on Research Infrastructures (ESFRI). As an equivalent of the ESFRI, Roadmap PRRI is open for all scientific domains.
Background:
The Polish Roadmap for Research Infrastructures was established in 2011 and updated in 2014. At present, it includes 53 projects, among which 30 are national projects, and 23 are international ones, while 28 are already in their implementation phase. Both establishing and updating the Roadmap was a fully bottom-up process which covered all scientific domains.

In June 2019, the Ministry of Science and Higher Education (now: Ministry of Education and Science) announced a second update of the Roadmap. The comprehensive assessment of the projects submitted was conducted by the interdisciplinary advisory panel of experts set up by the Minister of Science and Higher Education. The assessment conducted by the panel was complemented by an external evaluation of each of the projects done by two independent experts (one national and one international).

It is worth noting that the inclusion of the research infrastructure in the Roadmap does not involve any financial commitment from the Ministry or other public authorities. According to the Act on Higher Education and Science, it gives however certain advantage (additional points) when applying for funding to the Ministry. There was also a clear link between being included in the Roadmap and having a possibility to apply for the EU structural funds under financial perspective 2014-2020.

Background:
In view of the growing importance of batteries in a number of areas, including notably transport and energy, a safe, circular and sustainable battery value chain will be increasingly essential. Having batteries that are more sustainable throughout their life cycle is key to achieve our ambitious climate targets. This is also at the core of the Sustainable Batteries Regulation proposed by the Commission in December 2020.

English name: Multi-annual institutional funding for research programme in public research institutes and universities
Description: This initiative allowed public research institutes and universities to benefit from multi-annual institutional funding for research, with funding amounts determined on the basis of institutional performance indicators.
Objective(s): Promote an efficient and responsible public research system
Background: The main improvement in S&T system evaluation consisted on the evaluation of institutions according to the institutional performance indicators. Such evaluation took place during the first six months of 2013 and it was agreed between the MSES and PRO/HEI on a three years basis. In the future it will depend on the results of external evaluations. This reform of research funding was launched by the new Act and the Decision on the Multi-annual institutional funding for research programme in public research institutes and universities 2013-2015, which was adopted on 6 June 2013 (Official Gazette 69/2013). The performance–based funding has contributed to the autonomy and responsibility of universities and research institutes. Institutes decide autonomously about the internal distribution of allocated financial means for improving research activities with the final aim to meet evaluation criteria which include international competitiveness, scientific recognition, high-quality publishing, research results and outcomes with the impact on socio-economic potentials. The total funds allocated by the State budget amounted to around €6.6m in 2014 while there is an intended decrease in these resources for around 7% in 2017 to €6.2m. Majority of these resources (85%) were allocated to the seven Croatian universities while 26 public institutes received only 15%. The universities have established the Fund for the development of universities and carried out a public call at the universities’ level for research projects to allocate the given resources. The systemic and integrated data on granted funds are presently missing.

English name: STRATEGIC ROADMAP FOR AUSTRALIAN RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURE
Description: The National Research Infrastructure Roadmap identifies priority research infrastructure for the coming decade in areas that will underpin research in which Australia can and needs to excel, to deliver long-term national benefit and foster strategic international partnerships.
Objective(s): To provide advice to the Australian Government on future priorities for strategic investment in those key national research infrastructure capabilities that would support and develop Australia’s research capacity and underpin research and innovation outcomes over the next five to ten years.|To work closely with the research sector, stakeholders and experts on identifying strategic priorities and future planning for national research infrastructure (NRI) facilities.|To conduct regular priority setting and investment planning, acknowledging technology and scientific changes over time.|To provide guidance to Government to support critical national research infrastructure facilities, such as projects within the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), to operate with long term certainty.
Background:
Australian research infrastructure investment has been underpinned through four previous roadmaps: the 2006 NCRIS Roadmap, which underpinned the investments through the original NCRIS program; the 2008 Strategic Roadmap for Australian Research Infrastructure which underpinned the investments through the Super Science Initiative; the 2011 Strategic Roadmap for Australian Research Infrastructure, which was unfunded and not implemented and the most recent 2016 National Research Infrastructure Roadmap (2016 Roadmap).

The 2016 Roadmap was commissioned as part of the National Innovation and Science Agenda (NISA), and published in May 2017. The 2016 Roadmap identified nine focus areas and 36 priorities that require support to ensure that Australia maintains its leadership role in undertaking world-class research, especially in emerging research areas.

The Australian Government has developed the 2018 and 2020 Research Infrastructure Investment Plans in response to the 2016 Roadmap. The Australian Government made a 12 year, $4 billion investment to support Australian researchers with world-class research infrastructure from 2017-18 to 2028-29. Of this, $393.1 million was provided through the 2018 Investment plan and $157 million through the 2020 Research Infrastructure Investment Plan, to NRI facilities managed through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy program.

The Government also committed to regular Roadmaps (every five years) and Investment Plans (every two years) to ensure NRI is constantly reviewed and recalibrated to support our research and innovation system. The development of the 2021 National Research Infrastructure Roadmap is currently underway.

Description: The Austrian programme "benefit” promotes research and development of ICT products and services aimed at maintaining and improving the quality of life of older people and helping them to live more independently as long as possible.
Objective(s): Enhancing innovation for improving the quality of life of older people
Background:
Funding is provided for innovative, application-oriented projects in cooperation between business enterprises and research institutions or social service providers, with substantial involvement of end users. Applications for funding under the benefit programme can be submitted by companies, research institutions, researchers, social service providers, end users (older people, NGOs, professional associations), public authorities (provincial governments, local authorities), and consortia.

The Active and Assisted Living Programme (AAL) is a European R&D programme of 20 EU Member States with the financial support of the European Union (Art. 169). In analogy to "benefit”, AAL provides targeted funding for the development of products and services designed to enhance the quality of life of older people. Additional programme goals include fostering innovative ICT based products and services for ageing well at home, in the community and at work.

Description: ESS supports interdisciplinary, multidisciplinary and transdisciplinary projects, long-term research projects and projects on currently little investigated themes with a scientific pioneering function in the study of the Earth System.

Background:
Austria has a long tradition of funding multidisciplinary and transdisciplinary research, and the research community is trained to do research in this manner. There are no problems with multidisciplinarity in Austria but programme funding in this respect has decreased.
Calls and projects will be aligned with the newly initiated global Future Earth Programme of the Alliance (e.g. Belmont Forum, ICSU, UNU, UNESCO), which is designed as an inter- and transdisciplinary programme. The projects will also contribute to multilateral agreements, such as

- the Memorandum of Understanding on the creation of a Swiss-Austrian Alliance to support research into sustainable development in European mountain regions (www. chat-mountainalliance.eu)
- the Operational Programme Slovenia-Austria, helping to develop the Austrian higher education and research sphere (inter-institutional cooperation), and in cases of long-term research to make use of existing long-term research sites and infrastructure.

Cooperation with international partners is welcome but granted research projects must be coordinated from Austria. A total of no more than 20% of the granted funds may be passed on to foreign partners; any transfer of grant money to foreign project partners must be well-founded.

Background:
The Austrian centre for Digital Humanities (ACDH) is established at the Austrian Academy of Sciences (ÖAW) and started to operate in 2014. It has been initiated in a wider effort to support Social Sciences and Humanities (SSH) through (large) research infrastructures like CLARIN-ERIC (Common Language Resources and Technology Infrastructure) and DARIAH-EU (Digital Research Infrastructure for the Arts and Humanities).

The Austrian centre for Digital Humanities (ACDH) addresses the growing need for the digitalization of research materials in the humanities. The digitalization of historical documents is a strong trend in the social sciences and humanities. Thanks to digitalization, historic documents that have so far been hardly accessible by the research community or a wider public become usable for research. The digitalization makes research cooperation across Europe easier, more cost and time efficient, as well as centrally accessible through databases.

The Incentives Fund aims to provide financial support to plans, programmes and projects aimed at contributing to the achievement of STI policy objectives set by institutional planning instruments.
Objective(s): Provide financial budget to plans, programs and projects developed under the objectives and scientific, technological and innovation policies established in the National Plan for Science, Technology and Innovation.

Policy based on the National Science, Technology And Innovation Plan (2015-2021).

English name: PERFORMANCE BASED OVERHEAD FUNDING IN PUBLICLY FUNDED R&D PROJECTS
Description: Regarding the academic RDI support programs of TUBITAK, the legislation for funded RDI project overheads has been updated in a way to increase according to the performance of the institution.
Objective(s): To enhance R&D performances of universities.|to trigger R&D and innovation based activities within the academic institutions.
Background: Regarding the academic RDI support programs of TUBITAK, the legislation for project overheads has been updated in a way to increase according to the performance of the institution; and hence the R&D and innovation based activities are expected to trigger within the academic institutions. Each university that carries out TÜBİTAK academic RDI projects are paid an overhead up to 50% of the project budget, in addition to the project budget based on universities’ performance that are assessed annually based on objective criteria. The project overhead vary from university to university depending on their performance. A higher level of performance lead to a higher project overhead for universities. This also means an additional R&D budget for universities that compete to raise their level of performance.
Responsible organisation(s): Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey (TÜBİTAK;Türkiye Bilimsel ve Teknolojik Araştırma Kurumu)

English name: NATIONAL NEW IDEAS AND PRODUCTS R&D FUNDING PROGRAM
Original name(s): TÜBİTAK 1005 - Ulusal Yeni Fikirler ve Ürünler Araştırma Destek Programı
Description: The aim of the program is to support applied research and / or experimental development projects for the purpose of developing a new national / international product / process / method / model that will decrease dependence on foreign technology and / or increase international competitiveness.
Objective(s): To decrease dependence on foreign technology and / or increase our country's competitiveness.|To provide financial support for R&D projects which aim to develop frequently imported devices and materials domestically, without violating the patent rules.
Background:
Within the context of the program, the R&D projects are funded to create new features and new products by making additions to frequently used technology intense products.
The project duration is maximum 18 months.

Project proposals are evaluated under the following six dimensions: National Gain, Aims and Goals, Innovation level, Methodology, Project Management, Impact

English name: 6550 LAW ON SUPPORT FOR RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURES
Original name(s): 6550 sayılı Araştırma Altyapılarının Desteklenmesine Dair Kanun
Description: The research infrastructures are evaluated and funded based on their performance, in accordance with The Research Infrastructures Law (Law 6550) which was enacted in 10 July 2014 and secondary level legislation was enacted in 28.08.2015.
Objective(s): To enhance competitiveness and sustainability of research infrastructures.
Background:
Research Infrastructures Committee (RIC), which is composed of the Minister of Industry and Technology, the chairman of the Presidency of Strategy and Budget, Minister of Education, the deputy chairman of Science, Technology and Innvovation Council (STIPC), the deputy chairman of Education and Training Policies Council, the head of the Council of Higher Education has been the main governing body. RIC is authorized to determine research centres that can operate under the Law, regulate policies that are related with research infrastructures, and supervise financial issues including the budget allocation. RIC is also responsible for preparing the national roadmap for research infrastructures by taking into account ESFRI Infrastructures. The initial studies for the national roadmap is still in progress.

The Law introduces new financial and managerial measures for research infrastructures in universities.As indicated in the 11th Development Plan, in order to increase the accessibility of research infrastructures within higher education and public institutions and to prevent repetitive investments, it is aimed to prepare an inventory of machinery-equipment, human resources, research activities and testing services.

Recently; Turkey has reorganized its INFRA policy implementation domain; towards a better ERA integration for Turkish landscape; priorities are now more defined. Beginning from 2017, 7 major research institutes (mostly among from recipients of UYGAR Program) have been prioritized and supported with a dedicated regulation under the name 6550 - Turkey’s Research Infrastructure Law (TRIL). The TRIL members are listed below; METU MEMS Center, Bilkent University National Nanotechnology Research Center (UNAM), Izmir Biomedicine and Genome Center (IBG), Sabanci University Nanotechnology Research and Application Center (SUNUM), Turkish Accelerator and Radiation Laboratory (TARLA), The Center for Solar Energy Research and Applications (METU-GUNAM), Ankara University National Center for the Sea and Maritime Law (DEHUKAM)

The purpose of TRIL is to ensure the more efficient use and sustainability of research infrastructures, Professional management of research infrastructure, to manage sustainable finance, Facilitated personnel recruitment with different status and competitive wage policy, to be open 24/7 to all researchers and to monitor and to evaluate the performances of research infrastructures.
As the first step for this reorganization; the first ever version of “Turkish National Roadmap on INFRAs”, has been recently launched which is expected to be published publicly through the end of the year 2021.

The R&D Centers Performance Index (2019), which is the seventh of the R&D Centers Performance Index study since 2012, was carried out by the General Directorate of Strategic Research and Productivity. Studies were realized through the data of 641 R&D Centers within the scope of the R&D Centers Performance Index (2019).

Cumhurbaşkanlığı Eğitim ve Öğretim Politikaları Kurulu)|The Council of Higher Education (YÖK;Yükseköğretim Kurulu)

Description: TUBITAK 1505 "The Support Program for University-Industry Cooperation" aims to promote the transfer of knowledge stock and technologies of universities and public research institutions to industry, based on the technological needs of companies, which are residing in Turkey and committing to exploit the project outputs in Turkey.
Objective(s): To contribute to the production, dissemination and commercialization of knowledge and technology via multi-disciplinary RDI projects|To increase the effectiveness of university-industry collaboration|To encourage SMEs to involve more in R&D activities|To bridge the technological competence gap between university and industry
Background:
This program aims to contribute to the commercialization of knowledge and technology, which are generated within the university/public research centres and institutes in line with the industry needs, to the private sector companies which are based in Turkey and committed to the exploitation of research results. In this program, the private sector companies are "customers" and research organizations are "implementers" in the RDI projects. TUBITAK revised the programme in 2012 to further facilitate research commercialization, originated from university based R&D activities. The programme now particularly focuses on dissemination and commercializing knowledge created in universities and research institutes via transferring it to both SMEs and large firms as products or processes.
The maximum project budget is increased from 0,3 to 1 M TRY and the maximum period of funding is 24 months. SMEs are encouraged with a higher funding rate of 75 %. A new evaluation scheme is introduced to monitor the production and market success, at which the companies are monitored one year after the project is completed.
Responsible organisation(s): Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey (TÜBİTAK;Türkiye Bilimsel ve Teknolojik Araştırma Kurumu)

Description: This initiative gives visibility to those individuals, organizations and businesses that are making significant changes in the society through innovation.
Objective(s): The objective of this initiative is to distinguish good ideas able to value added. Such ideas should be able to benefit the society and to create economic value for the innovator.
Background:
The initiative to award an honorary prize for innovation was created by the "Fundación Pro Innovación" in 2007 and has been carried out annually since that date by the organizers. The establishment of the award responds to the conviction that rewarding and spreading the capacity of those who are "making a difference" contributes to improving the quality of life in the countrys economic progress and has had the support of the Government of Chile since the year of its creation.

There are twelve different categories eligible for an award, 2 special recognitions nominated by the Avonni community of experts and jury and 3 regional recognitions selected by experts in regions.

Original name(s): Пилотный проект по созданию национальных исследовательских университетов
Description: The National Research University (NRU) initiative aims to provide competitive financial support (mainly as institutional funding) for leading universities carrying out cutting-edge programmes for education, R&D and knowledge transfer.
Objective(s): Promoting at the global level HEIs capable to boost human capital in S&T, to create and commercialise new technologies, to develop innovative approaches to professional education and training.
Background:
The pilot version of the NRU initiative was initiated in 2008, but the current NRU agenda together with the list of selected beneficiary HEIs was adopted in 2010. There are currently 29 NRUs. The first two of them were selected in 2008 by a special Presidential Decree, without performance evaluation. The first open evaluation procedure was completed in 2009 with 12 NRUs selected. The second evaluation procedure in 2010 granted the NRU special status to 15 more institutions. The total budget of the NRU initiative (2009-14) included Federal Budget appropriations of RUB 49.8 billion and non-budgetary funding (from development institutions) of RUB 45 billion.
During the last years the initiative has not been supported by budget funding.

Description: The program Research platforms, a program previously known as Bridge, supports collaborative and multidisciplinary academic projects that guarantee the transfer of knowlegde to industry, the non-profit sector, or the public sector.
Objective(s): To stimulate the transfer of knowledge to industry, non-profit, or the public sector.|To stimulate research on areas of key importance to the Brussels region.|To stimulate cooperation between different kind of RDI actors.
Background:
Since 2010, six research platforms have been launched in the Brussels Capital Region. In 2010, three ICT research platforms were created in the following fields: 2D/3D Imaging, Knowledge Management, and Mobile Computing Applications. In 2011, two research platforms were launched in life sciences: NANOIRIS (nanomaterials) and CLINICOBRU (clinical research). In 2012, similar platforms were created in the fields of environment (sustainable building, wind energy for urban houses). 2014 saw the launch of the E HEALTH platform. In the last years, calls for projects were launched on issues such as cybersecurity, energy autonomy, personalised medicine and integrated care. More recently, a call for projects was launched on new Approaches of Testing. This is a direct result of the covid crisis and a commitment to make a difference through research and innovation.
In the field of health, testing is a key step in ensuring the safety of the environment, the effectiveness of a treatment, or in making a diagnosis.
Today, new demands are being made in this area. Tests must be effective but also ethical, more humane and involve a more rational and sober use of available resources, whether material or living. The next calls for this program will be also in line with the long term strategy of the Regional Innovation Plan.

Description: El PNPC otorga reconocimiento a la calidad de la formación de los programas de posgrado con el fin de incrementar las capacidades científicas, humanísticas, tecnológicas y de innovación del país, y así, contribuir al bienestar social de la población, la sustentabilidad y la atención a los problemas prioritarios nacionales.
Objective(s): Fomentar la mejora continua y el aseguramiento de la calidad del posgrado nacional, para incrementar las capacidades científicas, humanísticas, tecnológicas y de innovación del país, que incorporen la generación y aplicación del conocimiento como un recurso para el desarrollo de la sociedad y la atención a sus necesidades, contribuyendo así a consolidar el crecimiento dinámico y un desarrollo más equitativo y sustentable del país.
Background: Reconociendo la importancia de los programas de posgrado de alta calidad, CONACYT se unió en 1991 con la Secretaría de Educación para crear el PNPC. La actual política de CTI se enfoca en apoyar la incorporación de grupos subrepresentados -madres jefas de familia, mujeres indígenas y personas con discapacidad- en los posgrados dentro del PNPC. Establecer dentro de los nuevos criterios de evaluación del PNPC la existencia de un protocolo institucional de atención a casos de violencia de género, perspectiva de igualdad de género, no discriminación con integridad y apego a la ética. Establecer nuevos criterios de evaluación en el PNPC para la incorporación de instituciones interculturales, además de las que favorezcan la inclusión de las poblaciones en condiciones de vulnerabilidad.

Description:
The High-Tech Strategy 2025 sets the mid-term strategic orientations for Germanys R&D and innovation activity: reinforce the S&T base, enhance innovation and job creation, and help address global challenges to improve peoples lives. The HTS also aims to improve and accelerate the transfer of research into new products and services. The High-Tech Strategy 2025 focuses on three major
fields of action.
Objective(s):
1 Tackling the major societal challenges
The strategy focusses on research that is geared to current and future needs and that is relevant to people’s everyday lives. The goal is to achieve technological and non-technological innovations, including social innovations, which focus on benefiting the people. To this end, the strategy is developing missions and setting concrete goals which unite the support of science, business and society. The High-Tech Strategy 2025 is specifically promoting research into issues that are relevant to the German economy and society. The Focus is in particular on the areas of Healthcare, Sustainability, Climate Action and Energy, Mobility, Urban and Rural Areas, Safety and Security, and Economy and Work 4.0.|2 Strengthening Germany’s future competencies
The strategy aims to systematically and consistently evolve future competencies for a progressive Germany. To this end, it is promoting key enabling technologies that also open up new and disruptive innovation potential with their broad range of applications and strengthen the German economy in international competition. At the same time, the promotion of research and technology is accompanied with additional training and further education measures.|3 Establishing an open innovation and venture culture
For innovative results, the strategy promotes innovative forms of cooperation that create spaces for ideas and involve new actors in the innovation process. To ensure that research results feed even more effectively into practical application, the strategy is strengthening transfer, supporting open forms of innovation and the development of leapfrog innovations, promoting entrepreneurial spirit and innovative strength in SMEs.
Background:
In September 2018, the fourth edition (after 2006, 2010 and 2014) of the High-Tech Strategy was adopted by the German government. The HTS is developed further as a comprehensive, interdepartmental innovation strategy. New topics were added and new instruments for funding innovation introduced. The upward trend in investments in research and development is continued.

The HTS is considered to be a living, learning process which is continuously reconsidered. A consulting body, the High-Tech Forum, which consists of representatives of science, industry and society, is charged with developing proposals for the strategy‘s further development and implementation. In 2020, the BMBF realized a pilot for a participation process with seven regional dialogues. The objectives were to foster cooperation of traditional and new actors in order to strengthen innovation topics relevant to the region and to regionally relevant innovation topics and to provide regional ideas as inspiration for the federal innovation system.

Following a review, the strategy now includes twelve missions in areas where solutions to major challenges can only be found in cooperation with all stakeholders. These missions unite science, business and society behind common goals. HTS has linked up topics in various fields of innovation policy across Federal Ministries. Aspects related to funding are addressed in connection with efforts to improve general conditions. Individual fields of technology are seen as contributions to realising important social policy aims or as innovation drivers for other fields of technology (“key technologies”), while social change is considered to be an important prerequisite for the generation of technological knowledge. International and interdisciplinary co-operation will be further enhanced through appropriate measures.

Under the umbrella of the current High-Tech Strategy, all of the Federal Government‘s departments are developing joint aims and implementation steps to which all players in innovation activities – at the municipal, national and European levels – can orient their efforts.

English name: SMART SPECIALISATION STRATEGY AS PART OF THE NATIONAL R&I STRATEGY 2020
Description: As expressed in Malta's 2020 national R&I Strategy (published in 2014), eight thematic areas of smart specialization have been identified. These are: tourism product development; maritime services; aviation and aerospace; health, with a focus on healthy living, active ageing and e-health; resource-efficient buildings; high value-added manufacturing with a focus on process and design; and aquaculture. In addition, ICT was identified both as a horizontal enabler across all specialisation areas, as well as a Smart Specialisation niche in itself.
Objective(s): Identify, through an entrepreneurial discovery process, those niches within the economy where Malta could have a particular advantage in innovation. It is intended that Malta R&I activities align with the eight thematic areas as outlined in the strategy.
Background:
The National R&I Strategy (including smart specialisation) will be complemented by a dedicated R&I Action Plan. Maritime services is a mature and diversified economic sector in which Malta has a historic legacy and world-level profile. Malta has built a strong portfolio in avionics research, a relatively high critical mass of human resources as well as numerous established international R&D links in the area. Innovative e-health solutions as well as solutions for active and healthy ageing will be given particular consideration because both of these focus areas benefit from the integration of medical sciences with other areas where Malta has a strong knowledge base; such as ICT, social sciences and engineering. Both have a clear economic objective and the potential for a strong economic impact. The construction sector in Malta accounts for 4% of GVA and 5.4% in terms of employment (2012 data) however these figures have been decreasing over the past years. There is scope for exploring innovative solutions in the sector which address water scarcity and energy (dependence on fossil fuels, take up of renewable energy sources, etc.), both of which remain two of Malta’s major economic challenges. In manufacturing, two focus areas for innovation are process innovation (through optimisation of resource use, energy efficiency, automation etc.) and innovation in product design (product development, prototyping, etc.). Malta’s aquaculture industry has developed to its present status over a period of around twenty years. R&D is carried out both within the public and the private sector. Malta has developed a good degree of know-how in this sector and has participated in a number of EU-funded R&D projects.

The 2020 National Research and Innovation Strategy identified "Smart, Flexible Specialisation" as one of its main goals. Eight thematic areas of Smart Specialization have been identified which are listed as: (a) Tourism product development, (b) Maritime Services, (c) Aviation and aerospace, (d) Health with a focus on healthy living and active ageing, and e-health, (e) Resource-efficient buildings, (f) High-value added manufacturing with a focus on processes and design, (g) Aquaculture. As part of the implementation of the smart specialisation strategy, a dedicated Action Plan is presently being drafted to support, inter alia, inter disciplinary research at the interface of the identified specialisation areas. In June 2014, the Malta Council for Science and Technology launched the National Research and Innovation Strategy 2020, which set out Malta’s strategy for the forthcoming seven-year period. A decision was made to separate the strategic vision from the rolling R&I Action Plan, which aims to implement the action lines identified in the Strategy and which is currently being finalised. Following the launch of the Strategy, in 2014 a consultation process was launched to identify which measures already in place or in the pipeline, address the action lines of the strategy. The process involved extensive consultations with over 20 entities and ministries and a first list of measures was drawn up. Three iterations of this process took place between February 2014 to February 2015, to ensure that the latest information was available, that the ministries were properly engaged, and also to give time for the stakeholders to develop their plans further and concretise their measures, timelines and budgets. As part of the monitoring mechanism being set up to oversee the implementation of the Strategy and roll out of the Action Plan, two groups were set up: the Steering Group and Core Group. The groups started meeting since the inception of the drafting of the Research and Innovation Action Plan. The Core Group meets at Permanent Secretary level and is responsible for deciding on priorities for action as well as timeframes, resources and budgets on the basis of recommendations made by the Steering Group. The Steering Group meets at the level of Heads of Public Entities and Organisations or their high-level delegates. In the last quarter of 2014, the Steering Group and Core Group started meeting regularly, to begin filtering the measures and identifying those that could stimulate R&I and help achieve the 7 ambitious targets set in Chapter 9 of the Strategy. In 2015 MCST organised another round of focus groups as part of the ongoing entrepreneurial discovery process which engages academia, business, government and civil society as part of the Smart Specialisation Strategy. The process has enabled further sub-specialisation and the identification of Malta’s niche areas in the European and/or internationalisation arena. With the assistance of the European Commission’s Policy Support Facility, MCST is now finalising key performance indicators for monitoring the Strategy’s implementation and ensuring that the Action Plan remains on target to achieve its goals. Aquaculture: There is a good degree of collaboration between the public and private sector, however there is scope for exploring further consolidation of existing strengths by focusing on areas of common interest among different players. Infrastructure investments in the area include plans for a local hatchery. Maltese aquaculture can therefore capitalise on these strengths and differentiate itself as a leading innovator in aquaculture. Aviation and aerospace is a relatively new economic sector which has grown rapidly, attracted several foreign investors, and has diversified to include a number of niches such as maintenance, repair and overhaul and aircraft registration among others. There is scope for further investment to raise the level of achievement to the next level by venturing into the high value-added engineering market in order to move up the value chain in specific niches within the aerospace sector. Tourism is a key pillar of economic activity in Malta. The sector is well established and mature and there is a good degree of collaboration among operators. The sector is not R&D intensive but must innovate in order to remain attractive and competitive. Consultations yielded several avenues for innovation activity, however innovation in tourism product development was repeatedly highlighted as a key niche where Malta has potential for growth through innovation. In addition to linkages with other specialisation areas such as ICT and health, this specialisation area should involve extensive collaboration with the creative industries. Innovation in resource efficient buildings would transform the sector by increasing value-added, increasing green jobs and growth while at the same time addressing a societal challenge which is in itself a business opportunity. This specialisation area will focus on solutions for improved resource efficiency in new and existing buildings through, inter alia, demonstration projects and optimisation. Maritime services currently offered are varied but are still fragmented. There is therefore scope for improved clustering of maritime services. Malta’s drive towards becoming a maritime hub should include a drive to foster innovation in maritime engineering, ICT, design and services. ICT plays an important role in R&D and innovation in all sectors by facilitating the development of new goods, processes and services to modernise the economy and transform it to a knowledge-based one. Computer and related activities constituted 11.7% of the intramural R&D expenditure recorded in 2010 and 5.4% of the total innovation expenditure for the same year. The main research expenditure was on software consultancy and supply. In addition, ICT is one of the areas where Malta’s participation in FP7 is strongest (around 14% of FP projects involving a Maltese participant were in 8 - Achieving smart, flexible specialisation the ICT field). Malta’s participation in COST actions also indicates significant activity, with around 14% of Actions in which Malta participates being in the ICT Domain. All consultations undertaken in the preparation of the present Strategy acknowledged the crucial role of ICT innovation in all sectors of the economy. In manufacturing, while its share of GVA as a percentage of total GVA has decreased over time, the GVA in real terms of the manufacturing sector has increased over the past years. This sector remains predominant for research and innovation investment. Statistics for 2010 indicate that manufacturing activity encompassed 65.4% of all innovation expenditure and 62.2% of intramural R&D expenditure. This indicates clearly that, in spite of shifts towards the services sector, the manufacturing sector is still strong and should therefore be sustained through a greater focus on innovation niches within this sector. Various data sources (such as public R&D expenditure, participation in the European Cooperation in Science and Technology – COST, and publications) indicate that "health and medical research" is a significant component of Malta’s R&D investment. However, there appears to be significant fragmentation within it and there is scope for further exploration of innovation potential in this area.

Description: The German Federal Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF) had conducted a pilot process to draw up a roadmap for large research infrastructures (RIs). This 2013 published roadmap provides an overview of RIs that were selected in this process or that were currently being established. One distinguishing feature is that it only includes those projects for which there is in principle a public funding intention. In August 2015, after an evaluation of the pilot process, a revised and consolidated national roadmap process was announced, which was concluded in September 2019 with the announcement of the prioritised concepts for the new updated roadmap for RIs.
Objective(s): The efficient access to large RIs is essential for every scientific system. High investment costs and long-lasting construction phases of RIs require a fair strategic prioritisation process. The national RI roadmap process serves to prepare and prioritise - in terms of research policy - future and long-term investments in national and international scientific infrastructures with German involvement. General objectives of the national RI roadmap process are - the applicability to all scientific disciplines, - the support of political decisions on contribution to European/international RIs, - the realisation of a transparent process with external assessment - and the provision of planning reliability for selected projects at an early stage. In principal, though always subject to unforeseeable budgetary constrains, considerable public funding of (mainly) the investment costs of prioritised projects is intended for the development phases that should have a maximum duration of 10 years. On the other hand, the planned duration of the user-financed utilisation phases of RIs must be at least 10 years following their completion.
Background: BMBF had conducted a pilot process from 2011 to 2013 to draw up a roadmap for large RIs which received widespread support from across German science and research community. The 2013 published roadmap - during the pilot process initially restricted to the responsibility of BMBF - provides an overview of RIs that were selected in this process or that were currently being established. One distinguishing feature is that it only includes those projects for which there is in principle a public funding intention. A revised national roadmap process was announced to the public in August 2015 coping the responsibilities of all RI relevant ministries. The process was open to participation by all interested universities and non-university research institutions that were planning to develop new RIs. A publication of the updated national roadmap was released in September 2019. Currently, the BMBF revises experiences gained within the roadmap process completed in 2019 with regard to a new prioritization process.

Description: The Scheme supports research and innovation (R&I) collaborative initiatives and is divided into two options. Option A provides opportunities for collaborative initiatives between Maltese entities and at least one foreign entity of proven track record of excellence. Option B provides opportunities for Maltese entities intending to submit a Horizon Europe proposal as the coordinator of a consortium to engage a service provider (local or foreign) who will be supporting the applicant through proposal writing and submission.
Objective(s): To enable academia and industry to create and sustain international collaborative networks focused on developing joint R&I.|To contribute towards achieving the goals of the R&I Strategy with the potential that of any such activities become self-sustaining or generate longer-term outcomes.
Background: In 2015, the Malta Council for Science and Technology launched a survey to understand the needs of academia when it came to internationalisation of R&I efforts. The results of the survey pointed to the need for a scheme that would provide financial assistance to academics wishing to forge links with foreign centres of R&I excellence. IPAS 2015 was only open to academics. Subsequent to the launch of the scheme, feedback from industry indicated a desire for this scheme to be extended. Given the feedback from industry, and the need to find an improved way of supporting networking in R&I for both academia and industry, IPAS 2016 was opened up to industry players. Proposed activities to be funded through this award should promote internationalisation, for example, through: (i) the development of joint teaching curricula for Masters or PhD students (ii) placements for local researchers in foreign institutions for the purposes of furthering research & innovation collaboration (iii) the arrangement of strategic and targeted visits by local academics/researchers and representatives of private entities to foreign entities in order to participate in research & innovation activities of an exploratory and developmental nature (iv) the organisation of seminars or workshops on a particular research and innovation area in Malta that would benefit from the participation of foreign experts (v) the development of transnational research & innovation proposals for submission to third party-funders, e.g. Horizon Europe, etc. In 2019, we added another R&I funding opportunity for Maltese entities intending to submit a Horizon Europe proposal as the coordinator of a consortium to engage a service provider (local or foreign) who will be supporting the applicant through proposal writing and submission.

Description: The European Open Science Cloud offers Europes 1.7 million researchers and 70 million science and technology professionals a virtual environment to store, share and re-use their data across disciplines and borders, generated by the Big Data revolution.
Objective(s): The objective of the European Open Science Cloud is to integrate existing networks, data and high-performance computing systems and e-infrastructure services across scientific fields, within a framework of shared policies, standards and investments.|Making research data openly available can help boost Europes competitiveness, especially for start-ups, SMEs and companies who can use data as a basis for R&D and Innovation, and can even spur new industries.
Background: With the adoption of the Digital Single Markets strategy on 6 May 2015, the Commission announced the launch of a cloud for research data – the ‘research open science cloud. The European Open Science Cloud aims to create a trusted environment for hosting and processing research data to support EU science in its global leading role. Commissioner Moedas first flagged the initiative at the ERA of Innovation Conference, in June 2015. In a joint blog post, Commissioners Oettinger and Moedas further explained that the initiative will combine existing and future data infrastructures, offering secure and seamless access to European researchers for storing, managing and processing data from different sources. The Commission appointed a High Level Expert Group on the European Open Science Cloud to advise on the scientific services to be provided on the cloud and on its governance structure. The European Council and Member States welcomed the initiative in the Conclusions on Open, data-intensive and networked research as a driver for faster and wider innovation, adopted at the Competitiveness Council of 28-29 May 2015. Among various conclusions supporting the building blocks of the EOSC, they contain clear indication of support. The European Parliament also called on the Commission to move ahead with the initiative. The Parliament adopted a REPORT on Towards a Digital Single Market Act, in the plenary vote of 19 January 2016.
Responsible organisation(s): European Commission (EC;)
