Original name(s): ESS som drivkraft for fremtidens vækst - Strategi for den danske ESS-indsats 2.0
Description: The European Spallation Source (ESS) is a multi-disciplinary research facility, which Denmark together with Sweden is cohosting. In order to exploit the full potential of the Danish investment in ESS, an independent working group has worked out a strategy for the Danish ESS effort.
Objective(s):
The strategy focus on the following 8 key target scenarios:

The strategy identifies 8 target scenarios within to main focus areas. For each target scenario the strategy contain one or more initiatives which the working group has proposed to organize.

Focus area A: ESTABLISHMENT OF LEADING RESEARCH ENVIRONMENTS RELATED TO MATERIALS TECHNOLOGY ESS FORMS THE BASIS FOR GROUND-BREAKING INNOVATION AND GREEN TRANSION
Target scenario 1: World class materials research environments must form the basis for exploiting ESS potential
1.1. Establishment of further lighthouse environments at Danish universities
1.2. Annual summit meeting with ESS light-house environments
Target scenario 2: Tripling the neutron user environment should ensure adequate international clout for the Danish materials research environments
2.1 Action plan for training new neutron users
2.2. New and intensified focus on life science
2.3 Outlining a possible ESS-EMBL partnership
Target scenario 3: Comprehensive bridge building with ESS must give researchers in Denmark access to leading knowledge environments
3.1. Agreement on Danish involvement in the ESS operational phase
3.2. Preparation of Danish strategy for collaboration with ESS DMSC
3.3 Investigating the options for a Danish “outstation” by ESS

Focus area A: ESS FORMS THE BASIS FOR GROUND-BREAKING INNOVATION AND GREEN TRANSION
Target scenario 4: Danish companies and knowledge institutions must produce materials research for specific green solutions
4.1. Focus on the potential of materials research in relation to the green transition
4.2 Nordic conference on the contribution of materials research to the green transition
4.3 Action plan on the green transition and materials research
Target scenario 5: Cooperation and experience sharing between companies, universities and GTSs must be a source of new ideas and innovation
5.1 Exploration and establishment of a common industrial portal to help companies with advanced materials analysis
5.2 Strengthened involvement and collaboration with the business promotion system
Target scenario 6: The discoveries and results from materials research must be exploited through commercialisation and spin-outs
6.1 Analysis of the need for a materials oriented entrepreneur initiative
Target scenario 7: New value propositions must strengthen the marketing efforts with respect to foreign companies
7.1 Better knowledge base concerning the target group of relevant companies as well as the preparation of value propositions and marketing initiatives
Target scenario 8: ESS establishes opportunities for high-tech supplier companies
8.1 Examination and action plan for the Danish supplier contribution to ESS
Background:
ESS officially became the European Spallation Source ERIC on October 1, 2015. The Founding Members of the European Spallation Source ERIC are the Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, France, Germany, Hungary, Italy, Norway, Poland, Sweden, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. Founding Observers of the European Spallation Source ERIC, who intend to become Members, are Belgium, the Netherlands and Spain. ESS is currently under construction in Lund, Sweden, and the Data Management and Software Centre (DMSC) is based in Copenhagen, Denmark. The international orientation of ESS can be seen throughout the entire organisation. The Lund-based staff now includes employees from nearly 50 different nations. The ESS User Program is expected to begin in 2026. When the facility is completed an estimated two to three thousand visiting scientists will come to ESS annually to perform experiments. Most users will be based at European universities and institutes, and others within Industry. In order to exploit the full potential of the facility, Danish stakeholders from universities, companies and national/local authorities have worked out a strategy for the Danish ESS effort. The first strategy was presented in 2015. After five years it was decieded to renew the strategy. The "new strategy was presented in 2020.

Description: On 27 November 2015 the Dutch National Research Agenda was published. The Agenda enhances multi- and disciplinary research and strengthens joint programming. The new structure of NWO should encourage multidisciplinary research as well.
Objective(s): NWO is changing. The biggest change is that once the new NWO Act becomes effective on 1 February 2017, NWO will have a structure with an Executive Board, a separate NWO Institutes Organisation (Netherlands Foundation of Scientific Research Institutes) and three domains that are closely connected with each other: Sciences (former EW, CW, ALW, N/FOM); Applied and Engineering Sciences (former TW/STW) and Social Sciences and Humanities (former MaGW en GW). The intention is for NWO and the current ZonMw to integrate into a new organisation with effect from 1 January 2019.
Background:
The report 2025 - Vision for Science, choices for the future, the Dutch government stated that the basic position of Dutch science is good. The Netherlands can be proud of its research and its researchers. However, additional collaboration and connection are needed to maintain a leading scientific position and to further increase the contribution to society. This starting point was the guiding principle for the NWO strategy 2015-2018 and – following on from this – for the new governance and organisation of NWO.

The reform was a result of the institutional (NWO) evaluation (2013) as well as the internal policy evaluation and institutional (2014).

Description: The infrastructure fund supports research infrastructures in Iceland by co-financing purchase of equipment, databases, software and any other research infrastructure that is important for scientific progress.
Objective(s): The aim of the Infrastructure Fund is to improve the support for research infrastructures.
Background:
The Infrastructure Fund was established in 2013, building on and extending the role of the former Equipment Fund. The aim of the action was to improve the support for research infrastructures. In 2019 legislation was changed to provide an independent board for this fund, which is tasked with finalising a roadmap for research infrastructures to form the basis for prioritisation of infrastructure funding for the future.
In 2020 the fund called for RIs to apply to be on a national RI roadmap. There was an emphasis on collaboration between institutions for RIs to be eligible. The roadmap will be published in both Icelandic and English in July 2021. In 2021 the fund allocated resources according priorities defined by the roadmap with 80% of funds going to roadmap projects and 20% to other RIs

English name: The International Science and Business Belt
Description: Korea is attracting foreign hi-tech firms and research institutes into the "International Science and Business Belt (ISSB)" currently under development by providing them with tax incentives and financial support. In creative research environment, ISSB is designed to become a national growth hub, where global talents, science and businesses interact with each other.
Objective(s): ISBB with creative research environment is designed to become a national growth hub, where global talents, science and businesses interact with each other. The Central District of the ISBB will function as a hub of basic science research and house the Institute for Basic Science (IBS) and RAON, a Korean Rare Isotope Accelerator.|Outstanding scientists from home and aboard will be provided with pleasant residential environment of a global standard, which will help them settle down with ease and convenience.|In order to facilitate the translation of basic science research outcomes into practical applications, a science-based business environment will also be created, where researchers and related industries can work together closely.
Background:
Various strategies will be implemented to create a new growth engine through ground-breaking advancement of basic science, thereby laying the foundation for ISBB to become a world-class science-based innovation cluster. This will transform Korea into a powerhouse of basic science. ISBB will be a mega science and business complex, intended to house world-class basic science research organizations and related business facilities.
- Establishment of a world class basic science base
- Creation of future new industry through science and business convergence
- Realization of low carbon green growth

Current progress of ISBB

A. ISBB innovation cluster development: The ISBB site (3,075,000 square meters in Daejeon) was authorized by the Ministry of Land and Transportation in July 2014. A new ISBB development plan was developed by the Ministry of Science, ICT and Future Planning in August 2015. The ISBB site creation was launched in June 2016. The first round of land sale to innovative companies was carried out in October 2017.

B. The Institute for Basic Science (IBS): 28 world-class research groups have been organized since 2011. The construction of the IBS headquarter building was complete in January 2018

C. The heavy Ion accelerator (RAON): The conceptual and technical design of RAON was completed in October 2013. The designing and production of accelerator devices and modules started in 2014. The construction of the accelerator facility started in February 2017.

Description: Colombia BIO is a national strategy aimed at turning Colombia into one of the most important bio-economies in the region.
Objective(s): Promoting conditions to know, assess, preserve and use biodiversity, contributing to sustainable and social inclusive economic development.|Strengthening research capacity to know, assess, preserve and use biodiversity and its ecosystem resources in a sustainable manner.
Background:
Colombia currently has an important base of natural, social, economic and political resources, which makes it a potential bio-economy in the long term. Having 53% of its continental territory covered with natural forests, 311 types of continental and marine ecosystems, being the first country in the world as to diversity of birds and orchids and second in diversity of plants, amphibians, fresh-water fish and butterflies, means a unique comparative advantage for the country. Colombia has a Biodiversity National Policy (the country is signatory of the Biological Biodiversity Agreement, Law 164 of 1994), a National Policy for Commercial Development of Biotechnology and a National Development Plan 2014-2018 (Law 1735 of 2015), where green growth is one of its transversal strategies.
This programme issued three calls in 2016: one for the development of products derived from Colombian biodiversity, one for supporting research projects on Colombian biodiversity, and one to strengthen research collaboration between UK and Colombia on biodiversity.
Responsible organisation(s): Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation (MINCIENCIAS;Ministerio de Ciencia, Tecnología e Innovación)

English name: NATIONAL SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY AND INNOVATION PLAN
Original name(s): Plan Nacional de Ciencia, Tecnología e Innovación 2015-2021
Description: The National Plan of Science, Technology and Innovation 2015 - 2021 defined five strategic areas: education, health, environment and water, energy, food and agriculture.
Objective(s): Contribute to social welfare and strength countrys knowledge based activities through social appropriation, articulation and application of Science, Technology and Telecommunications.
Background:
It was coordinated with the related sectors in order to join efforts in project management orientation; at the same time were sharp as a key element the use of converging technologies (info, bio, nano, cogno) whose potential lies in solving problems in an optimum and sustainable manner. The STI plan involves sectorial projects that intend to impact on the country´s social and economic progress; the development of two smart cities as a national transformation concept of traditional urbanism towards a sustainable metropolises. It also aims to promote and strengthen the Intelligent Community Centers (CECI) into spaces to reduce the digital divide and training, entrepreneurship and the use of online services, focused on high risk national communities focusing on the use of technology information and communication tools. On the other hand, the PNCTI 2015-2021 proposes the creation of a Knowledge-Based Economy Policy as the major integrative framework of policies that promote human capital formation, excellence science, outstanding research and development that’s allows entrepreneurship and start-up innovation processes and increases competitiveness, productivity and social well-being of Costa Rica.

The plan was shared with the public sector through an official presentation on February 2015. The Ministry of Science, Technology and Telecommunications (MICITT) led its construction in 2014. Along with the government, stakeholders from academia and industry shared their thoughts and recommendations on how to best use the country’s comparative advantages in order to become more competitive. The 2015-21 PNCTI builds on inputs from foresight exercise carried out earlier 2014.
Responsible organisation(s): Ministry of Science, Innovation, Technology and Telecommunications (MICITT;Ministerio de Ciencia, Innovación, Tecnología y Telecomunicaciones)

Valley means concentration (totality of entities) of the capacities in research, studies and knowledge-intensive business generally in one area, with common or interrelated infrastructure, geared towards building knowledge economy and thus enhancing Lithuania’s economic competitiveness.

Although, final phase of Maritime valley in Klaipėda city were financed from 2014-2020 EU financial period (project - "Establishment of the Marine Valley kernel in the context of phase 2 of the infrastructure renewal", 11,5 million Eur).

English name: PARTICIPATION IN THE EUROPEAN STRATEGIC FORUM ON RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURE
Description: The European Strategic Forum on Research Infrastructures (ESFRI) is a strategic instrument created by the Member States and the European Commission to develop the scientific integration of Europe and to strengthen its international outreach.
Objective(s): ESFRI delegates have been nominated by the Research Ministers of the MMEE to develop a joint vision and a common strategy, including regularly updated Roadmaps.
Background: SPAIN participates in the following ESFRI infrastructures: (1) LIFEWATCH; (2) EURO-ARGO (European component of a world wide in situ global ocean observing system); (3) Svalbard Integrated Arctic Earth Observing System (SIOS); (4) EMSO (European Multidisciplinary Seafloor and Water Column Observatory); (5) ELIXIR (European Life-science Infrastructure for Biological Information); (6) EATRIS (European Advanced Research Translational Research Infrastructure in Medicine); (7) ECRIN (Pan-European infrastructure for clinical trials and biotherapy); (8) CTA; (9) ESS; (10) European X-ray Free Electron Laser (XFEL); (11) PRACE; (12) International Fusion Materials Irradiation Facility (IFMIF); (13) JHE (Reactor); (14) ESS (European Social Survey); (15) SHARE; (16) CESSDA; (17) DARIAH; (18) INSTRUCT; (19) EPOS European Plate Observing System; (20) EMBRC (Marine Biological Resource Centre); (21) EuroBioimaging; (22) Openscreen; (23) ECCSEL; (24) EU SOLARIS; (25) Facility for Antiproton and Ion Research (FAIR); (26) European Extremely Large telescope (E-ELT); (27) EST European Solar Telescope (2016). Spain also is member of the following infrastructures: CERN; ITER/F4E; ESO; EMBL; ESRF; SESAME; ILL; INL; EFI; GBIF and IODP/ICDP.

Description: The foundation serves as a catalyst for scientific and human progress by supporting interdisciplinary research, establishing collaborative research networks and developing strategic partnerships. In addition to providing financial support, NOMIS endeavors to develop and strengthen the conditions conducive to the pursuit of high-risk basic research.
Objective(s):
NOMIS Awards are presented to exceptional and pioneering researchers who have made significant contributions in basic research, have the manifest potential for transformative future discoveries, and have the ability to inspire the world around them. Their bold ideas and unique approaches involve interdisciplinary collaboration and apply a broad range of methods, building bridges across the boundaries of disciplines. The NOMIS Award enables these exceptional, established scientists to continue exploring unconventional academic paths, thereby opening up new research fields and collaborations.|NOMIS fellowships support emerging, early-career researchers who, like other NOMIS researchers, demonstrate the potential to lead groundbreaking, high-risk basic research. With interdisciplinary collaboration at the heart of their innovative ideas and approaches, these researchers build bridges across the boundaries of disciplines.

NOMIS research grants support unconventional research projects led by researchers who have demonstrated exceptional scientific capabilities and leadership. The grants enable scientists to spearhead pioneering research to answer bold questions and advance yet unexplored approaches across scientific and academic disciplines. We award research grants to investigators with an excellent track record in leading groundbreaking, high-risk basic research.

English name: TURKISH ACADEMY OF SCIENCES STEM CELL WORKING GROUP
Description: TÜBA - Stem Cell Working Group organizes several meetings and courses at national and international level with the participation of all relevant partners and publishes reports on the subject.
Objective(s): To stimulate RDI on stem cell technologies that will allow the acquisition of new information that may benefit patients, as well as the renewal of the basic knowledge in cell biology.
Background:
TÜBA conducts its main tasks with various working groups in order to make investigations and consultations to determine scientific priorities and scientific issues; to ensure the dissemination of scientific approach and thought in society; to propose changes to the government, the social status of the Turkish scientists and researchers, their living levels, their income and the legislative changes regarding the special benefits and privileges required by such activities; to ensure the appreciation and acceptance of the importance of science to the public. Working groups established by the decision of the Academy Council on important, prioritized and current issues shall perform the following tasks.

The main missions of working groups are:
*To follow the current developments and knowledge about the subject,
*To share their knowledge experiences in coordination with relevant stakeholders and students in the relevant disciplines,;
*To contribute to the development of an interactive environment that encourages the preparation of research projects involving new approaches, giving priority to cooperation with in-house, national and international similar groups,
*To consulate for national and international projects and/or organizations,
*To organize at least one event per year in the form of congresses, conferences, seminars or symposiums,
*To contribute to all kinds of information activities through books, brochures and similar publications, as well as through the media and the internet,
*To organize sessions in national and international congresses.
Responsible organisation(s): Turkish Academy of Sciences (TÜBA;Türkiye Bilimler Akademisi)

Original name(s): Fasiliti Perkongsian Kemudahan dan Peralatan Saintifik Nasional
Description: In line with NSTIP 2021-2030 Action Plan
Objective(s): The National Scientific Facilities & Equipment (NSFE) aims to encourage sharing of facilities and scientific equipment among STI community and enhance research and development (R&D) cooperation.|The initiative also plans to encourage the industrial and public sector to collaborate in R&D activities.
Background:
The NSFE was developed by the Malaysian Science and Technology Information Center (MASTIC), a division under The Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation (MOSTI) that contains information on facilities and scientific equipment in Malaysia. The equipment is owned by government departments and agencies, government research institutions and public higher education institutions.

The sharing of facilities and scientific equipment for this initiative refers to the following scope and definitions:
i. Sharing scope of facilities and scientific equipment includes equipment rentals, R&D cooperation, offers of analytic services or technical advisory and sharing of the analysis result;
ii. Definition of STI facilities refers location or places where research and scientific activities are pursued such as a laboratory, the monitoring centre and site of testing; and
iii. The definition of scientific equipment refers to machine, equipment, apparatus, accessories or parts that are specific or unique worth RM100,000.00 and more which utilized for research activities, analysis, teaching/learning, testing and inspection services.

MASTIC will continue increasing the number of facility and scientific equipment in NSFE. Therefore, MASTIC encourage various agencies / departments and the private sector to list their owned scientific facilities and equipment worth RM100,000.00 in the NSFE by register it on the KRSTE.my portal.

This initiative will also help the STI community execute R&D&C activities to produce new products, processes or technologies via rentals or acquire analytics services without the need to procure expensive equipment. Moreover, the industry could gain technical advice in STI through the sharing of facilities and scientific equipment. The country also benefited by having centralized information on facilities and equipment scientific that eventually avoid procurement of similar scientific equipment.
Responsible organisation(s): Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation (MOSTI;Kementerian Sains, Teknologi dan Inovasi)

Theme(s): Research infrastructures

Description: This Framework provides a systematic approach to transform Malaysia into a knowledge-intensive economy by design.
Objective(s): To enhance the competitiveness and sustainability of Malaysian industries|To enhance the quality of life of the people (rakyat).|To bridge the innovation chasm through collaborative platforms
Background:
The 10-10 Malaysian Science, Technology, Innovation and Economic (MySTIE) Framework is an integration of 10 key Malaysian socio-economic drivers with 10 global leading science and technology drivers aligned to our strengths and needs. This Framework provides a systematic approach to transform Malaysia into a knowledge-intensive economy by design.

It aims to generate shared economic prosperity across the diverse ecosystems in the country and shift Malaysia up the global innovation value chain. This Framework will enable key sectors of the economy to become more knowledge intensive and innovation driven. This will enhance the competitiveness and sustainability of Malaysian industries. It is designed to enhance the quality of life of the people (rakyat).

English name: KNOWLEDGE RESOURCE FOR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY EXCELLENCE
Original name(s): Knowledge Resource for Science and Technology Excellence 2.0
Description: Upgraded as an Integrated Science, Technology and Innovation (STI) Data and Information Platform. Designed with a better web interface and more user-friendly system features such as elastic search, dynamic reporting, option for bulk upload, Web-based equipment & services booking and more.
Objective(s): To be the main reference center for the country's STI strategic information to support the needs of the STI community through quality knowledge management.|To facilitate the flow and access of STI information between the government and private sectors to support national policy in the development of STI.|To facilitate the flow and access of STI information between the government and private sectors to support national policy in the development of STI.
Background:
Since 2019, The Malaysian Science & Technology Information Center (MASTIC) of MOSTI has dedicated significant efforts to enhance and update the richest possible Knowledge Resource for Excellence in Science and Technology.

In line with NPSTI 2021-2030 Action Plan, The KRSTE.my 2.0 Portal will serve as a Single Point of Access to the wealth of knowledge artifacts from various internal and external systems and sources. It will become the biggest reservoir of information on anything and everything to do with Research, Development & Commercialization in the area of Science, technology and Innovation.
KRSTE.my enables:
• Knowledge exchange in secure environment.
• Context based search using semantic technology.
• Content enrichment with content sources from local and international institution.
• Informative decision making through state of the art of dashboard facilities.
• Visual display of content by showing the relationships and big picture view of experts in various field of research.

It's definitely the most comprehensive reference point for those seeking the most elusive of data and information, whether one's looking for general data about all the organizations and institutions involved in R&D, or specific, seemingly classified information about funds available for R&D, to even valuable breakthrough advice about accessible R&D Facilities (i.e. labs, specialized equipment etc.) as well as information on relevant personnel, researchers and experts, including their CVs. Such data have never been as easily accessible ever before and never from one site, as easily as now, only with the KRSTE.my 2.0 System.

The KRSTE.my Portal is aimed at overcoming the shortfalls relating to accessibility and sharing of information among agencies and organizations that has resulted in the creation of countless "islands" of information.
MASTIC, as the center for S&T information, aspires to prevent such redundancy by creating a central repository of all the national knowledge artifacts.KRSTE.my is a central part of MASTIC in its efforts to enhance its service delivery and ensure those seeking for data and knowledge have instant and unprecedented access to such information to propagate a quantum leap in the end results among those involved in STI and RD&C. It is the ardent desire of MASTIC to use KRSTE.my to prevent wastage of funds, resources and time while simultaneously becoming the platform for Knowledge to be shared and benefited by all.

Original name(s): Pelan Halatuju Industri Elektrik dan Elektronik : Pembangunan Teknologi 2021-2030
Description: This roadmap is to establish an E&E one stop-center, development of market-pull moon-shot programs, and the creation of emerging technology open innovation programs.
Objective(s): To establish solid governance and a one stop-center to provide support to the industry in terms of technical advisory and advocacy and shared facility.|Creation of market-pull moon-shot program by harmonizing inter-ministries policies, strategies and investments, which will enable more SMEs and local companies/ vendors to participate in the implementation of projects in identified niche areas|Creation of emerging technology open innovation program  to support market pull moon-shot program and encourage R&D program to develop Malaysian made critical components/ systems/ integration needed in niche sectors.
Background:
Realizing the potential and opportunity in E&E industry globally, the government aims to increase high value added of local industry production by more than 40 per cent, based on scientific advances and high technology innovation. This roadmap identifies strategic thrusts and key program that includes:
i. The needs to establish solid governance and a one stop center to provide support to the industry in terms of technical advisory and advocacy and shared facility;
ii. Creation of market-pull moon-shot program by harmonizing inter-ministries policies, strategies and investments, which will enable more SMEs and local companies/ vendors to participate in the implementation of projects in identified niche areas; and
iii. Creation of emerging technology open innovation program to support market pull moon-shot program and encourage R&D program to develop Malaysian made critical components/ systems/ integration needed in niche sectors.
Responsible organisation(s): Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation (MOSTI;Kementerian Sains, Teknologi dan Inovasi)

Description: The Malaysian Government recognized biotechnology as one of the key strategic drivers to propel the country’s social and economic development in pursuit of the status of a developed nation. For this purpose, the Government launched the National Biotechnology Policy (NBP) in year 2005 to further develop three economic sectors namely agriculture, healthcare and industrial manufacturing, as well as to support the growth of an enabling eco-system throughout the scientific, academic and business communities in the country.
Objective(s): To develop three economic sectors namely agriculture, healthcare and industrial manufacturing, as well as to support the growth of an enabling eco-system throughout the scientific, academic and business communities in the country.
Background: Currently NBP 2.0 is being drafted that aims to focus on 3 sectors, which are Agriculture , Healthcare and Industrial Biotechnology. The demand for skillful worker in the 3 sectors are highly sought after and the relevant ministries are now conducting engagements with industry players to match the demand of the workforce with the courses offered in the higher education.

English name: MINISTRY OF AGRICULTURE AND FORESTRY - AGRICULTURAL R&D SUPPORT PROGRAM
Description: The R&D projects designed by public research institutions affiliated to the ministries, universities, TÜBİTAK R&D institutes/centers, non-governmental and professional organizations and private sector are supported.
Objective(s): To determine the priorities of the agricultural sector of Turkey|To improve the scientific and technological capacity on determined priority themes in agriculture.|To facilitate knowledge and technology transfer to related stakeholders
Background:
Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry provides non-refundable direct financial support to R&D projects for the purpose of improving the knowledge base and technologies in accordance with the needs of agricultural sector , transferring these know-how and technologies to the farmers, agricultural industrialists and exporters, as well as increasing the R&D capacities of the organizations in agricultural sector.

R&D projects carried out by the universities, non-governmental organizations, vocational institutions, farmer’s organizations and private sector are supported within the scope of "Communiqué on the Procedures Applied in Supporting the Research and Development Projects issued subject to agricultural law no 5488".

The Ministry started R&D project supports in 2007 and the secretarial tasks regarding the project application, project evaluation and monitoring of approved projects are performed by General Directorate of Agricultural Research and Policies (TAGEM).
Responsible organisation(s): MINISTRY OF AGRICULTURE AND FORESTRY- GENERAL DIRECTORATE OF AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH AND POLICIES (TAGEM;TARIMSAL ARAŞTIRMALAR VE POLİTİKALAR GENEL MÜDÜRLÜĞÜ)

Water that is more sensitive to the coordination of research activities in hydraulic fields. The water cycle project will identify hydrodynamic hot spots in rivers, lakes, and groundwater, as well as flood prone areas and draughts.

Coastal and oceanography: This research investigates the interaction of waves with hydrodynamic river estuaries and coastal erosion.

Water research: This research focused on the impact of hydrodynamic water to environmental ecologies (impact of pollutant/contamination load (Suspended Solid, Water Quality) on ecosystem)

Description: The Presidential Decree No. 68 on the Industrialization Executive Committee (the “Decree”) was published in the Official Gazette No. 31274 dated 14th October 2020. The Decree establishes the Industrialization Executive Committee (the “Committee”), a high-level body, which is likely to have a say in the fields of industry, technology and public procurement in Turkey going forward.
Objective(s): To improve domestic production and technological capability through various ways including public procurement|To facilitate investment, production and financing processes|To encourage the localization of critical products in supply chains and enrich domestic production diversity, and take steps to strengthen the capital structures of manufacturing industry companies|To strengthen the Turkish industry and technology ecosystem|To ease the control of public procurements in line with the indigenous production priorities|To increase competitiveness
Background:
The Committee consists of the President, the Vice President to be appointed by the Turkish President, the Minister of Industry and Technology, the Minister of Treasury and Finance, the Minister of Trade and the Head of the Strategy and Budget.

The Presidential Decree No. 68 grants broad authority to the Committee to decide on a wide range and The Committee’s scope of activities includes mainly industrialization, technology and domestic production. Among others, the prominent duties and powers of the Committee are as follows:
*To take decisions regarding public procurement as per the priorities of industrialization, domestic production, and national technology policies;
*To take necessary measures to facilitate the investment, production and financing processes of industrialists and technology manufacturers;
*To ensure investment in strategic areas where domestic production is limited;
* To take decisions on transactions regarding changes in the shareholding structures of companies that are critical for the country which could risk the continuity of domestic production and national security;
*To take decisions to increase the global competitiveness of the real sector by ensuring the coordination between institutions in areas such as finance, customs, environment, infrastructure, logistics and energy; and
*To take decisions to guide public practices with the aim of strengthening the capital structures of manufacturing companies, to encourage company mergers when necessary, to design policies that will increase productivity and to increase product diversity.

English name: FUNDING INITIATIVE FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF MODELS OF DATA INTERMEDIARIES
Description: The Federal Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF) is promoting the implementation of projects for the conception, establishment and further development of existing data intermediaries as a contribution to the Federal Government's data strategy.
Objective(s): Establishment of neutral data trustees to contribute to the consolidation and security of data stocks and enable their controlled use for a defined group of users, especially within the scientific system for research purposes oriented towards the common good.|Strengthen the position of data providers regardless of whether they are individuals or organizations through an appropriate access management system and protective measures to ensure information security and data protection.
Background:
With regard to the improved availability of data while at the same time maintaining basic data protection regulations and further development of data ethical principles, the subject of this funding guideline is the implementation of pilot projects for the conception, development and testing of technical and organizational exemplary solutions within the framework of data trust models. Approaches for practical testing and accompanying research (real laboratory approach) of data trust models in area-specific or cross-application fields are particularly welcome.

Funding can be provided for models in the field of scientific research as well as in the economic context to achieve data-driven innovation or new collaborative forms of cross-actor value creation. The subordinate goal is to create trust as an intermediary between data providers and users to improve the exchange of data for data-driven research purposes that are oriented towards the common good.
Responsible organisation(s): Federal Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF;Bundesministerium für Bildung und Forschung)

Approaches for practical testing and accompanying research (real laboratory approach) of data trust models in area-specific or cross-application fields are particularly welcome.

Funding can be provided for models in the field of scientific research as well as in the economic context to achieve data-driven innovation or new collaborative forms of cross-actor value creation. The subordinate goal is to create trust as an intermediary between data providers and users to improve the exchange of data for data-driven research purposes that are oriented towards the common good.

English name: RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURE ROADMAP OF THE FEDERATION OF BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
Original name(s): Mapa puta istraživačke infrastrukture Federacije Bosne i Hercegovine - konačni nacrt
Description: Research Infrastructure Roadmap of the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina (FBiH) summarizes the existing research potential of the Federation of BiH with a particular focus on the identification of research facilities, equipment, instrumentation and international cooperation, including the involvement of the FBiH in large European Research Infrastructures and projects.
Objective(s):
1. Increase investments in R&D.|2. Make distinction between teaching and research activities - enable higher engagement of teaching staff in research activities.|3. Establish conditions for the re-functioning of academic and research network BIHARNET.|4. Create a Smart Specialization Strategy taking into account the research potential identified in RI Roadmap.|5. Intensify activities for the participation in DARIAH infrastructure and consider the possibility of participating in other Large pan-European infrastructures.|6. Improve the Legal and policy framework. Analysis of the current legal and policy framework has shown insufficient regulation in the area of R&D in the Federation of BiH. Only a few Cantons have regulated this area, while others do not have legal and policy documents that regulate R&D. In the context of the development of RIs, it is important to clearly define which organizations are considered as scientific research organizations. Additionally, the terms “Research Infrastructures” and Research Infrastructure Roadmap” should be defined within legal and policy documents on the Cantonal and Federation level.

7. Encouraging Open Access to RI. As a result of the “Open Access Research Infrastructure in the Western Balkans Support Programme” implemented by RCC secretariat in 2020, the University of Sarajevo, the University of Zenica and the University of Bihać adopted an Open Access Policy to Research Infrastructures. Building on the experience gained in this program, the FBiH Ministry of Education and Science should encourage other research institutions to adopt their own Open Access Policy documents.
Background:
This document has been developed in close cooperation with the Regional Cooperation Council (RCC) that provided technical assistance to the FBiH Ministry of Education and Science in the Federation of BiH in this assignment. The technical assistance was provided as part of a broader action that included the provision of assistance to other Western Balkan economies with the final goal to contribute to creating the Western Balkans’ Roadmap of Research Infrastructures (WBRRI).
The mapping exercise in BiH was specific since it consisted of two separate parts. While the survey in the Federation of BiH was conducted between February and March 2021, the mapping of the RIs in other entity of BiH (Republic of Srpska) was conducted in 2019, which resulted in the creation of RI Roadmap of the Republic of Srpska. Since the same questionnaire was used, there was no need to conduct the same survey again in the entity Federation of BiH.
The target audience for the questionnaire was the research community of the Federation of BiH. Public and private universities and other higher education institutions were invited to complete the questionnaire by the FBiH Ministry of Education and Science. The completed survey questionnaires served as an input for the identification and evaluation of research infrastructure potential.
Additionally, the existing policy settings for research and innovation have been analysed with the particular emphasis on the following: the ongoing reforms of the research sector; the legal framework for research infrastructures; reviewing the existing strategic documents on research and innovation and the current status of the process of developing Smart Specialization Strategy.

Description: TÜBİTAK has launched "COVID-19 and Society: Social, Human and Economic Effects of the Pandemic, Problems and Solutions" call in order to reveal the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on socio-economic, social and industrial developments. The scope of these effects extended to behavioral changes, equality of opportunity, accessibility of work, education, food supply and communication as well as psychological and sociological changes.
Objective(s): To examine the current and/or anticipated problems and effects of the global pandemic of COVID-19 from the perspective of social and human sciences; and to propose solutions to those problems and effects.
Background:
It was strongly encouraged to adopt interdisciplinary approach to handle the multi-dimensional aspects of the pandemic.
The proposals were expected to address the following issues:
• Revealing the current situation and trend with evidence-based scientific data
• Short, medium and long-term projection, foresight, analysis and planning practices
• Proposing solutions that will contribute to the decision makers and practitoners in accordance with these analyses and foresights.

The call was open for 15 days in April 2020 and at the end of the call 682 proposals coming from 160 different institutions were evaluated within 20 days. After the scientifc evaluation, 97 projects were funded with a total amount of approximately 7 million TL.
For the dissemination of the results, a virtual event via YouTube live stream was held on February 22-23rd, 2021. The key findings of the funded projects were presented in five simultaneous sessions. In addition, an e-booklet titled “COVID-19 and Society: Social, Human and Economic Effects of the Epidemic – Findings, Results and Suggestions” is published on TÜBİTAK web site; covering the findings, results and suggestions obtained from the funded projects.
Responsible organisation(s): Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey (TÜBİTAK;Türkiye Bilimsel ve Teknolojik Araştırma Kurumu)

Description: TÜBİTAK ULAKBİM High Performance and Grid Computing Center is a national center providing high performance computing and data storage for all research institutions and researchers in Turkey. This center is referred to as the Turkish National e-Science e-Infrastructure (TRUBA) with the decree of the TÜBİTAK Executive Board. The expanding and reinforcement of computing and data storage resources needed for our researchers to compete with their colleagues in the national and international arenas is carried out by the recommendations of the Turkish National e-Science e-Infrastructure Advisory Board.
Objective(s): To provide high-performance computing and data storage to all research institutions and researchers in Turkey.
Background:
Since its incorporation, TÜBİTAK ULAKBİM has been providing research networks, high performance computing, data-intensive computing and scientific data warehousing services. When looking at the services provided today, we can see that it contains all the necessary components for the continuous and reliable operation of e-Infrastructures. It closely monitors projects, centers and policies related to technological developments such as cloud computing and Green Information Technologies and gives great importance to interoperability with all components of e-Infrastructure.
Services such as high-performance computing, data-intensive computing, scientific data warehouses and cloud computing are provided by the current infrastructure called TRUBA as of 2011, which is operated by the TRUBA Operation Center and was called TR-Grid until the end of 2010.
TÜBİTAK ULAKBİM started the high-performance computing studies with the 128 PCs purchased in 2003 with the budget of the institution, and then realized the TUGA (Turkish National Grid Infrastructure/TR-Grid) project with the demand from national researchers as well as the experiences and achievements achieved in international projects. The infrastructure was supported and expanded significantly between 2006 and 2008 within the scope of the TUGA project supported by TARAL with the approval of the TÜBİTAK Science Board.
In 2009, the project “TR-Grid Research e-Infrastructure Strengthening” was presented by applying to the Research Infrastructure Project Call of DPT (State Planning Organization). Within the scope of this project, TRUBA, formerly called TR-Grid, was supported by DPT until the end of 2011. Within the scope of the “Turkish National e-Science e-Infrastructure Strengthening” project, which is a continuation of the previous project, the infrastructure is being expanded and updated with the current technologies with the support of the Ministry of Development.
TRUBA, which has more than 1900 researchers from 114 different universities, provides direct service to contribute to scientific studies, carries out joint projects with different public institutions and research institutes and took part in 13 European Union Framework Programme Projects since its establishment, is an e-Infrastructure of strategic importance in the national sense.
In order to support and strengthen the established and developed National e-Infrastructure for it to compete in the international arena, a joint work should be carried out with the TRUBA Advisory Board under TÜBİTAK ULAKBİM. TRUBA Advisory Board was established in July 2010 with the decree of TÜBİTAK Science Board. The TRUBA Advisory Board includes representatives of the Ministry of Development, TÜBİTAK, universities, the public, defense industry and private sector. TRUBA Advisory Board is a unique board providing strategy, policy and technical consultancy for all stakeholders of the e-Infrastructures in Turkey, and operating similar infrastructures.
TRUBA serves researchers with ~ 17,500 processor cores, 80 GPUs and 4PByte Luster distributed file system.
The expanding and reinforcement of computing and data storage resources needed for researchers to compete with their colleagues in the national and international arenas is carried out by the recommendations of the Turkish National e-Science e-Infrastructure Advisory Board.
Responsible organisation(s): Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey-Turkish Academic Network and Information Center (TÜBİTAK ULAKBİM;TÜBİTAK Ulusal Akademik Ağ ve Bilgi Merkezi)
Theme area(s): Public research system
Theme(s): Open science and enhanced access to publications and research data|Research infrastructures
Target group type(s): Researchers, students and teachers
Target group(s): Established researchers|Postdocs and other early-career researchers

English name: TUBITAK 1002 - SHORT TERM R&D FUNDING PROGRAM

English name: FUNDING JUNIOR RESEARCH GROUPS IN EMPIRICAL EDUCATION RESEARCH
Original name(s): Richtlinie zur Förderung von Nachwuchsforschungsgruppen in der empirischen Bildungsforschung
Description: The Federal Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF) supports empirical education research projects of research groups to strengthen the national research landscape and the need for longer-term employment prospects after completion of doctorate programmes.
Objective(s): Support holders of junior professorships or those in the early career phase in contributing to their scientific profile acquiring performance and professional science skills.
Background: Individual and joint projects are funded that are carried out within junior research groups. The initiative builds on other programmes for young scientists launched by BMBF under the previous framework program and funding priority “Science and University Research”. Traditionally, there has been a focus on thematically targeted measures for promotion of doctorates and supporting networking between the sponsored doctoral candidates.

English name: FUNDING INITIATIVE FOR RESEARCH ON REDUCING BARRIERS TO EDUCATION
Original name(s): Richtlinie zur Förderung von Forschung zum „Abbau von Bildungsbarrieren: Lernumwelten, Bildungserfolg und soziale Teilhabe“
Description: The initiative provides funding to research and development projects in the field of educational research with the aim of reducing educational barriers.
Objective(s): Investigate the conditions for success and support the research-based development of practical approaches for promoting and supporting the education of children and young people in disadvantaged social and spatial circumstances.
Background: In Germany, social origin continues to have a decisive influence on educational success. For example, this is documented in the results of the National Education Report 2018. To give every child the basic equipment that gives him or her a chance for social participation remains one of the major educational policy challenges. Research can help at better understanding the conditions for equal chances in education and to develop suitable measures and instruments.
Responsible organisation(s): Federal Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF;Bundesministerium für Bildung und Forschung)
Shift(s) related to Covid-19: It can be assumed that risks posed by educational barriers have increased for certain groups due to the impacts of Covid-19. Therefore, the funded research gains further relevance in aiding in the reduction of educational barriers through socio-spatial approaches.

English name: COHE REGULATION ON “JOINT APPLICATION AND RESEARCH CENTERS IN HIGHER EDUCATION INSTITUTIONS”
Original name(s): YÖK- Yükseköğretim Kurumlarında Ortak Uygulama ve Araştırma Merkezleri Yönetmeliği
Description: With the regulation on "Joint Application and Research Centers In Higher Education Institutions" Joint Application and Research Centers are established by the coordinator higher education institute with the cooperation of more than one state higher education institution.
Objective(s): To conduct research that will contribute to scientific and technological development in priority areas determined within the scope of national goals and policies
Background:
The regulation on “Joint Application And Research Centers In Higher Education Institutions” was published on June 19, 2020.
Thanks to the initiative of CoHE, an important step was taken within the scope of the legal regulation that calls for the establishment of a joint research center where leading universities have the opportunity to share knowledge and experience widely in order to conduct strategically-important projects such as medicine, vaccines and seeds.

Gazi University, Ankara University and Middle East Technical University joined their forces with the initiative of the Council of Higher Education (CoHE) and established the Neuroscience and Neurotechnology Center of Excellence (NÖROM) for joint research and development. Thus, the first model in Turkey that aims to make efficient use of public resources through the joint R&D efforts of the leading universities on strategic issues, was realized.
Responsible organisation(s): The Council of Higher Education (YÖK;Yükseköğretim Kurulu)
Theme area(s): Public research system|Science-industry knowledge transfer and sharing
Theme(s): Research infrastructures|Transfer and linkages strategies
Target group type(s): Research and education organisations
Target group(s): Higher education institutes

English name: TENMAK - COMPETITIVE RESEARCH FUNDING FOR ENERGY TECHNOLOGIES
Description: Competitive research funding program for energy technologies is planned for the upcoming years in order to carry out, make, organize, support, establish and coordinate technical studies by TENMAK.
Objective(s): To increase and sustain the competitiveness of our country in the field of energy, mineral, ionizing radiation, particle accelerators, clean energy and nuclear technology|To meet the need for finance in energy sector innovation|Ro ensure the production of new products and the development of existing ones in energy sector|To provide and encourage a strong scientific environment for researchers in energy sector|To meet the R&D needs of affiliated, related and related institutions and organizations of the Ministry of Energy and Natural Resources
Background:
TENMAK ensures the production of new products and the development of existing ones in its own fields of work, that is the energy sector technologies; by providing a scientific environment for researchers, conducting scientific research in cooperation with public and private law professionals, coordinating and/or encouraging these researches, contributing to research and development activities. In the upcoming years competitive and non-competitive (invitation-based) research funding and scholarship programs are planned in order to carry out, make, organize, support, establish and coordinate technical studies in energy sector.

Legislative work on processes still continues and it is foreseen that the support processes will start before the end of the year 2021.

Collaborations can be developed to provide a scientific environment for researchers in the field of energy, mineral, ionizing radiation, particle accelerators, clean energy and nuclear technology, to conduct scientific research, to organize, support and improve existing ones.

Description: TENMAK Nuclear Energy Research Institute (NÜKEN) performs all kinds of research, development, innovation, design, technology acquisition, production, testing, localization activities which enable the use of ionizing radiation, particle accelerators, nuclear energy and nuclear technology.
Objective(s): To perform all kinds of research, development, innovation, design, technology acquisition, production, testing, localization studies that will make it possible to benefit from ionizing radiation, particle accelerators, nuclear energy and nuclear technology in the scientific , technical and economic development of our country.
Background:
With the Presidential Decree No. 57 published in the Official Gazette dated 28/03/2020 and numbered 31082, the Turkish Energy, Nuclear and Mineral Research Agency (TENMAK) was established and the RHTD Presidency in Ankara and the TGD Presidency in Istanbul were restructured as the Nuclear Energy Research Institute (NÜKEN) Presidency.

Responsibilities:
*To perform all kinds of research, development, innovation, design, technology acquisition, production, testing, localization studies, in cooperation with public and legal entities, that will enable the use of ionizing radiation, particle accelerators, nuclear energy and nuclear technology in the scientific, technical and economic development of the country,
*To perform, encourage, support, coordinate, monitor and develop programs and projects for R&D activities in the fields of ionizing radiation, particle accelerators, nuclear energy and nuclear technology,
*Preparing and presenting the national policy and strategy proposals to direct R&D activities for the benefit of the country,
*To ensure the wide use of the products developed as the results of R&D activities by public institutions and organizations, universities and the private sector, to cooperate with public institutions and organizations, universities and the private sector in this context, to carry out and support joint projects, to evaluate their demands, to encourage their participation in research, development, innovation, design, technology acquisition, production, testing and localization activities in these fields, to support the transformation of the outputs they will obtain as a result of research, development and innovation activities into commercial value,
*To carry out and make R&D related to the environment and human health in their own fields of duty,
*To provide measurement, analysis, dosimetry, metrology, calibration, conformity assessment, irradiation, intervention, technical support, production, testing, inspection, evaluation and consultancy services and other related services,
*To provide measurement, analysis, testing, inspection, conformity assessment, research, examination, consultancy, verification, evaluation, control and other related services that support regulatory activities,
*To carry out training activities on ionizing radiation, particle accelerators, nuclear energy and nuclear technologies,
*To carry out and coordinate all kinds of activities related to radioactive waste management such as collection, treatment, processing, transportation, storage and disposal of radioactive waste,
To prepare the National Radioactive Waste Management Plan for radioactive waste management,
To provide training and development of human resources in matters related to its field of duty, to give awards and scholarships within the framework of the procedures and principles to be determined by the Institution, to plan the work of the human resources to be sent to foreign countries on behalf of the Institution, to cooperate with and monitor other institutions and organizations for this purpose,
*To carry out research and development activities at home and abroad within the scope of the cooperation of the Institution with national and international institutions and organizations, to participate in the works of national and international institutions and organizations on behalf of the Institution,
*Organizing and supporting national and international congresses, seminars and training events, contributing to and participating in them scientifically and financially,
*To carry out studies on the establishment of research and development centers, laboratories and similar units needed within its body, to operate these and to provide the needed devices and equipment,

English name: TENMAK RARE EARTH ELEMENTS RESEARCH INSTITUTE
Description: TENMAK Rare Earth Elements (REE) Research Institute (NATEN) performs basic and applied research and development activities in order to develop and produce critical products and technologies related to rare earth elements (REE) and other critical elements.
Objective(s): To develop REE production technologies from domestic or resources and alternative sources in our country|To create a reliable and sustainable REE supply chain for our country|To develop advanced technological material production technologies containing rare earth elements
Background:
Rare Earth Elements Research Institute (NATEN) was established with the Presidential Decree No. 4 published in the Official Gazette No. 30479 of 15 July 2018. According to the Presidential Decree No. 57 published in the Official Gazette dated 28 March 2020, NATEN continues its activities in Ankara/Kazan Sarayköy Nuclear Research Institute campus within Turkish Energy, Nuclear and Mineral Research Agency (TENMAK).

TENMAK/NATEN conducts national and international studies to constitute the necessary information for short, medium and long term policies and strategies of our country on rare earth elements (REE) and other critical elements, obtain REEs in order to reduce the foreign dependency of our country and industry in raw materials, and develop technologies for the production of end products by using REEs that our developing sectors will need.

Rare Earth Elements Research Institute (NATEN), which continues its activities within the body of the Turkish Energy, Nuclear and Mineral Research Agency (TENMAK) according to the Presidential Decree No. 57 published in the Official Gazette dated March 28, 2020, carries out basic and applied research and development activities in order to develop and produce products and technologies related to rare earth elements (REE) and other critical elements.
Annex 503 of the 11th Development Program, which is one of the top policy documents of our country aiming at ensuring the security of raw material supply in the mining sector, states: “In order to meet the raw material needs of the energy sector and industry, exploration activities in the country and abroad will be increased, and the search for rare earth elements, boron and other metals with high economic potential will be given priority. ” titles are included. In this context, TENMAK NATEN carries out R&D activities in order to develop production technologies related to obtaining REE and other critical elements from the reserves of our country and recycling them from alternative sources such as coal ash, electronic wastes, mining wastes. With R&D studies on REE production technologies, TENMAK NATEN aims to reduce the foreign dependency of the developing energy sector and our industry on REE and other critical elements, to contribute to the reduction of the current account deficit by reducing REE imports, and to ensure supply chain sustainability for the defense industry.

In addition to NTE production technologies within TENMAK NATEN; necessary R&D activities are carried out for the production of high-temperature, abrasion and corrosion resistant advanced technological materials containing REE, which can be used especially in renewable energy and domestic automobile production.

TENMAK NATEN, which aims to gather all R&D studies related to REE production and end product production in our country under same roof, provides coordination by making necessary cooperation with public and private legal entities and industrial organizations. It also carries out joint projects and cooperation activities related to REE technologies, which is made within the framework of national and international bilateral or multilateral agreements.
Responsible organisation(s): Turkish Energy, Nuclear and Mineral Research Agency (TENMAK;Türkiye Enerji, Nükleer ve Maden Araştırma Kurumu)

Description: TENMAK Boron Research Institute conducts programs and projects in order to perform RDI on developing Boron products and technologies, as well as to expand their usage areas.
Objective(s): To increase the economic contribution of boron in our country by focusing on developing high value-added boron products and technologies and expanding their usage areas|To perform and support R&D activities|To transform RDI into production and added value
Background:
With the Law No. 4865 dated 4/6/2003, The National Boron Research Institute was established as a related institution of the Ministry of Energy and Natural Resources in order to perform, conduct, coordinate and contribute to RDI activities in cooperation with public and private legal entities conducting research in this field; in order to provide the necessary scientific environment for the different utiilization fields; in order to ensure the wide use of boron products and technologies, the production and development of new boron products in Turkey and in the world,

The responsibilities and organization of the National Boron Research Institute were rearranged in the 48th Section of the Presidential Decree on "The Organization of the Ministries, Related, Related Institutions and Organizations and Other Institutions and Organizations No. 4" published in the Official Gazette dated 15/7/2018 and numbered 30479. With the Presidential Decree No. 57, Boron Research Institute (BOREN) was established within TENMAK and started its activities on 20.08.2020.

TENMAK BOREN continues its activities in laboratories and pilot facilities within the designated R&D Center. By providing cooperation and coordination with the related public and private sector R&D and industrial organizations; It executes RDI programs and projects on delevoping boron products and technologies, as well as diversifying their usage areas; creates academic output in the form of scientific publications and organizes scientific events.

Boron Research Institute also supports boron laboratories' infrastructures with high-tech equipment in order to carry out and support boron R&D activities.

MISSION
In order to increase the economic contribution of boron in our country, by focusing on developing high value-added boron products and technologies and expanding their usage areas; to carry out and support R&D activities, to transform information into production, to provide effective information management and cooperation.

VISION
To be a pioneering institution that adds innovation and value to boron.

Description: The Industrial Transformation Research Hubs scheme provides funding to Eligible Organisations to engage in cutting-edge research on new technologies and economic, commercial and social transformation which support the development of research outcomes that benefit industry partners in the Industrial Transformation Priorities by supporting collaborative research activities between the Australian higher education sector and industry.

Background:

Original name(s): Araştırma Üniversiteleri Performans İzleme Endeksi - [Araştırma ve Aday Araştırma Üniversitelerinin Performans Değerlendirmesi]
Description: In order to evaluate research/candidate research universities performance, TUBITAK and Council of Higher Education has developed special performance evaluation tool, which ranks the research universities in Turkey. As a result of the performance evaluation, 16 research and candidate research universities are ranked according to 33 indicators under 3 dimensions: "Research Capacity", "Research Quality" and "Interaction and Cooperation".
Objective(s): To increase the research oriented competition among the research/candidate research universities|To evaluate research universities performance deeply with various research capacity, quality and collaboration indicators|To determine top 11 university as a research university and last 5 university as a candidate research universities|To specify top 5 research universities with the highest performance, which are provided additional allowance as an incentive and appreciation
Background:
In order to evaluate research/candidate research universities performance, TUBITAK and Council of Higher Education has developed special performance evaluation tool, which ranks the research universities in Turkey. This evaluation was performed for the first time in 2017, and is renewed and announced each year. The last announced performance evaluation was conducted in 2020 with the 2019 data. Performance evaluation which belongs to 2021 with the 2020 data is still ongoing.
Top 5 research universities with the highest performance, were provided with additional allowance as an incentive and appreciation.

After evaluation results, 20 research assistant staff for each 11 research universities and 10 research assistant staff for each 5 candidate research universities have allocated in 2019.

A special exception is defined for research/candidate research universities in the overhead ratios determined by TÜBİTAK based on the research performance of universities. In this context, 50% overhead ratio, which is the highest ratio, is given to research/candidate research universities in addition to their project budgets.

In TÜBİTAK 1004- Center of Excellence Support Program, research universities have special priorities and they are located in the center of the platforms, which are established under this program. Moreover, in TUBITAK 2232-A International Fellowship For Outstanding Researchers program, minimum 60% of the quota allocated for universities is belonged specifically to research universities. The co-financing of the research universities which have the Marie Curie COFUND project is covered specially by TUBITAK.

The priority sectors in the 11th Development Plan are matched with the research universities according to their competencies. These analyses are shared with the Presidency of Strategy and Budget to be used in decision-making processes, especially in investment programs. Thus, it will be easier to spend public resources more efficiently and based on competence. Research universities will be encouraged to establish academic units such as research centers, departments, and programs related to the matched specialization areas, and universities in the same priority sector and field will be encouraged to work together.

Original name(s): Programa Internacional de Investigação sobre Montesinho
Description: The International Research Programme of Montesinho is oriented to promote the scientific valorisation of the Natural Park of Montesinho through the development of R&D activities.
Objective(s): To promote the scientific valorisation of the Natural Park of Montesinho through the development of R&D activities in 5 areas, considered strategic: observation and knowledge of the Earth (including the use of satellite information and its integration in advanced information processing and artificial intelligence systems); climate and climate change; socio-cultural interaction dynamics over time; sustainable agriculture; biodiversity and biological resources, natural and cultural heritages and sustainable regional development.
Background:
The Natural Park of Montesinho (PNM) represents a mountain area with unique characteristics as it is the last relief in the north-east of Portugal that still belongs to the peninsular northwest and borders the Meseta Ibérica. It has an unequalled environmental richness, being integrated in the Natura 2000 Network and in the United Nations Iberian Meseta Biosphere Reserve.

In interface areas between distinct natural domains, as in this case of the Northwestern Peninsular and the Iberian Mediterranean Meseta, biodiversity is enormous and facilitates privileged areas for monitoring and further study of climate change, as well as developing timely mitigation measures and actions. In the case of the PNM, the mountain system has a relevant influence on the regional climate as shown by the studies and monitoring work developed in recent decades mainly under the Iberian Mountain Research Network.

Original name(s): Programa Internacional de Investigação sobre Montesinho
Description: The International Research Programme of Montesinho is oriented to promote the scientific valorisation of the Natural Park of Montesinho through the development of R&D activities.
Objective(s): To promote the scientific valorisation of the Natural Park of Montesinho through the development of R&D activities in 5 areas, considered strategic: observation and knowledge of the Earth (including the use of satellite information and its integration in advanced information processing and artificial intelligence systems); climate and climate change; socio-cultural interaction dynamics over time; sustainable agriculture; biodiversity and biological resources, natural and cultural heritages and sustainable regional development.
Background:
The Natural Park of Montesinho (PNM) represents a mountain area with unique characteristics as it is the last relief in the north-east of Portugal that still belongs to the peninsular northwest and borders the Meseta Ibérica. It has an unequalled environmental richness, being integrated in the Natura 2000 Network and in the United Nations Iberian Meseta Biosphere Reserve.

In interface areas between distinct natural domains, as in this case of the Northwestern Peninsular and the Iberian Mediterranean Meseta, biodiversity is enormous and facilitates privileged areas for monitoring and further study of climate change, as well as developing timely mitigation measures and actions. In the case of the PNM, the mountain system has a relevant influence on the regional climate as shown by the studies and monitoring work developed in recent decades mainly under the Iberian Mountain Research Network.
Responsible organisation(s): Foundation for Science and Technology (FCT;Fundação para a Ciência e a Tecnologia)

English name: SUPPORT SCHEME FOR RESEARCH AND INNOVATION PROJECTS IN THE FIELDS OF ENERGY AND WATER
Description: The R&I Scheme seeks to support R&I projects whose objectives are in line with national policies in the energy and water sectors
Objective(s): The Scheme is intended to boost and guide the direction of national R&I in the fields of energy and water over the upcoming decade. These fields bring together some of the most significant challenges being faced at a national level, where rapid population and economic growth as well as the impacts of climate change exacerbate pre-existing pressures stemming from Malta’s specificities.
Background: Under the Governance Regulation, Member States are required to set out national objectives and funding targets under the Research and Innovation Dimension for the upcoming ten-year period. In light of this it was determined and agreed between competent Ministries that a sector-specific strategy for R&I in energy and water would be developed by the Energy and Water Agency to take full advantage of the value-added and cross-cutting benefits of such targeted approach.

Description: “Turkey 2035 Technology Foresight Study" was initiated in October 2020 under the auspices of the STIPC and with the technical support of TUBITAK in order to determine strategic potential areas and emerging technologies that would scale up our economic and social benefits by 2035. The Study is planned to be completed in the second half of 2021.
Objective(s): To determine strategic priority areas and potential emerging technologies that would scale up our economic and social benefits by 2035.|To determine the main megatrends in order to analyze the current and early signals of economic, social, cultural, technological and ecological transformation for the next 15 years and beyond.
Background:
The rising uncertainties confronted globally by the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, has emerged the power of scenario-thinking, foresighting efforts and the need for evidence-based planning and use of digital tools to enhance decision-making and policy design within the STI agenda. In this context, in the second half of the year 2020, The "2035 Technology Forecast" study was initiated under the auspices of the STIPC and with the technical support of TUBITAK in order to identify strategic development areas and emerging technologies that could maximize economic, technological, environmental and social benefits by 2035.

In this context, a comprehensive analysis was carried out to determine the megatrends in order to analyze the current and early signals of economic, social, cultural, technological and ecological transformation for the next 15 years and beyond; both at national and global levels. Thanks to the foresight studies, reducing the uncertainty of the future that will come before us in the medium and long term and to take steps that will shape the desired future from today, may become possible and a vision of long-term risks and opportunities is to be provided. The sub-transformations and changes created by the megatrends have been examined in detail from the perspective of R&D and innovation system and technology development.

In accordance with the early outcomes of the Foresight Study on technological trends, one may expect a world where digitalization is becoming more integrated with daily lives and economies as fastes as never before and the world witnesses the rapid rise of digital technologies; especially artificial intelligience, internet of things; and the rising need for cyber security regarding the accelerating digitalization.

On the other hand, the COVID-19 pandemic has tremendously accelerated all the digitalization processes by all means; in the simplest terms of for instance social distancing technologies, by distance education system trials, by transforming health systems, and of course financial operations. The way we interact with the digital world is also changing, moving beyond behind the screens and keyboards to a combination of interaction modalities and connectivity in all terms.

In line with the early stage conclusions of the Foresight Study, the main paradigm shift is happening in a context of continuing technological development of ICT, AI, connectivity technologies, quantum computing, the rising need for cyber security, space technologies, new materials for chip technologies beyond silicon, digitalization and transformation of health technologies, bio and nanotechnology, clean and renewable technologies; green economy while the world is becoming hyper-connected as never before; as well as the environmental challanges rising such as climate change and drought.
In the final phase of the study which is planned to be completed in the second half of 2021, Advisory orientations and opinions of leading public institutions, senior private sector institutions in our country in terms of economic activities and/or R&D expenditures, venture capital funding organizations, technology-based startup companies and senior researchers/academicians, in order to determine the changes that are considered to have the most significant and transformative impact for our country will be taken through a detailed Delphi Survey which is currently under implementation and Focus Groups Meetings to be held subsequently right after the Delphi Analysis. It is hence planned to evaluate the possibility of the realization of the mega trends that may trigger global transformation and the impact of our country on the level of global competition.
