Original name(s): Plataforma Nacional de Infraestrutura de Pesquisa
Description: The National Research Infrastructure Platform (PNIPE) systematically maps and gathers information on research infrastructures in Scientific, Technological and Innovation Institutions (STIs) in the country, enabling access for the scientific and technological community and companies to existing laboratory facilities and research equipment, promoting their shared use.
Objective(s): Provide the scientific and technological community access to information on existing research infrastructures, including their location, applications and conditions of use.|Foster the research infrastructure’s potential of innovation by giving visibility and insights for companies to cooperatively improve their products and develop new technologies.|Encourage the shared use of resources and collaboration between research groups from different areas, institutions and regions, consolidating collaborations between them.|Optimize the use of laboratory facilities and scientific research equipment to avoid fragmentation and duplicated efforts.|Optimize the use of public resources in the preventive and corrective maintenance of existing infrastructures, as well as in the creation of new facilities and new equipment acquisition.
Background:
There is a lack of information about laboratories and equipment in Brazil. There is no consolidated information about their location, use and cost of use. In this context, the Brazilian Research Infrastructure Platform will drive the best use of existing research infrastructures. It will also promote integration, economy, synergy and improvement in the process of sharing existing infrastructures assets in the country.

Thus, it is essential to check the situation and conditions of use of the existing research infrastructure, in order to identify bottlenecks and lack of investment and support public policy makers with information that can guide government investments in the area.

Faced with the scarcity of resources, the government have improved their mechanisms for monitoring and evaluating their actions, increasing the importance of these mechanisms in the governance of ST&I policies. Initiatives that consolidates innovation ecosystems must be a priority by governments and entrepreneurs, who have increased investments in RD&I and infrastructure. In addition, they must intent to improve human resources and structural conditions for science and innovation, prioritizing greater interaction between public research and industry.

The Platform aims to optimize the use, availability and maintenance of research equipment, especially state-of-the-art equipment from multi-user laboratories. Original name(s): Plataforma Nacional de Infraestrutura de Pesquisa
Description: The National Research Infrastructure Platform (PNIPE) systematically maps and gathers information on research infrastructures in Scientific, Technological and Innovation Institutions (STIs) in the country, enabling access for the scientific and technological community and companies to existing laboratory facilities and research equipment, promoting their shared use.
Objective(s): Provide the scientific and technological community access to information on existing research infrastructures, including their location, applications and conditions of use.|Foster the research infrastructure’s potential of innovation by giving visibility and insights for companies to cooperatively improve their products and develop new technologies.|Encourage the shared use of resources and collaboration between research groups from different areas, institutions and regions, consolidating collaborations between them.|Optimize the use of laboratory facilities and scientific research equipment to avoid fragmentation and duplicated efforts.|Optimize the use of public resources in the preventive and corrective maintenance of existing infrastructures, as well as in the creation of new facilities and new equipment acquisition.
Background:
There is a lack of information about laboratories and equipment in Brazil. There is no consolidated information about their location, use and cost of use. In this context, the Brazilian Research Infrastructure Platform will drive the best use of existing research infrastructures. It will also promote integration, economy, synergy and improvement in the process of sharing existing infrastructures assets in the country.

Thus, it is essential to check the situation and conditions of use of the existing research infrastructure, in order to identify bottlenecks and lack of investment and support public policy makers with information that can guide government investments in the area.

Faced with the scarcity of resources, the government have improved their mechanisms for monitoring and evaluating their actions, increasing the importance of these mechanisms in the governance of ST&I policies. Initiatives that consolidates innovation ecosystems must be a priority by governments and entrepreneurs, who have increased investments in RD&I and infrastructure. In addition, they must intent to improve human resources and structural conditions for science and innovation, prioritizing greater interaction between public research and industry.

The Platform aims to optimize the use, availability and maintenance of research equipment, especially state-of-the-art equipment from multi-user laboratories. This Platform provides real-time monitoring of the information registered there, such as where the equipment is located, identify the cost of use and the availability of such equipment.

English name: SUPPORT NETWORK FOR INTERDISCIPLINARY SOCIAL POLICY RESEARCH
Description: The FIS supports endowed chairs, young professionals groups and research projects. Researchers are to establish themselves in social policy research and universities are to expand or establish new structures for social policy and social law research.
Objective(s): Strengthen independent social policy research.
Background: A strong welfare state depends on dedicated researchers who anticipate change and draw attention to its implications. Sound analysis of current changes in society and the world of work and their implications for welfare state or social policy arrangements is essential for informed social policy discourse. Against this backdrop, the Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs (BMAS) launched the Interdisciplinary Social Policy Research Funding Network (FIS) in 2016. With the network, the Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs aims to strengthen independent social policy research. Researchers should be able to establish themselves in the field of social policy research, and the relevant universities in the field of social policy and social law research should be able to expand or rebuild structures.
Responsible organisation(s): Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs (BMAS;Bundesministerium für Arbeit und Soziales)

Description: The funding of systemic, transdisciplinary and implementation-oriented mobility research is intended to show ways in which the complex mobility system can be made more sustainable.
Objective(s): Secure the individual mobility of people and improve the quality of life and environment, especially in cities.|Strengthen the innovative capacity of the German mobility sector.|Create a sound basis for sustainable innovation and transformation management.|Identify starting points, barriers and incentive options for the adaptation of sustainable forms of mobility, possible risks and long-term need for action for traffic and urban policy and planning (among others).|Better understand interactions and effects within the mobility system as well as between mobility and other sectors.|Provide orientation for forward-looking and directional policy and planning through comprehensive sustainability assessments.
Background: The “Sustainable Urban Mobility” research agenda is aligned with the goals of sustainable development that are defined internationally in the 2030 Agenda and nationally in the German Sustainability Strategy. The Federal Ministry of Education and Research's (BMBF) research agenda “Sustainable Urban Mobility” outlines how the sustainable design of urban mobility systems can be achieved with the support of research. The research agenda is the basis and the strategic framework for research funding and innovation policy support for the BMBF in the field of systemic urban mobility. It relies on a systemic perspective that considers the opportunities of new technologies in the context of mobility needs and the specific conditions on site. It integrates the results of participatory consultation processes in which numerous experts from science, municipalities, business and civil society have contributed their perspectives, needs and ideas from the 2017 agenda process: “Sustainable Mobility” and the 2017/18 agenda process: "Social-ecological Research."

English name: NATIONAL RESEARCH, DEVELOPMENT, INNOVATION AND ENTREPRENEURSHIP STRATEGY
Description:
The national Research, Development, Innovation and Entrepreneurship strategy for the period of 2021-2035 defines five priority areas (RDIE focus areas):
The national strategy will also define five priority areas for Estonian RDIE:
1. Digital solutions horizontally through other sectors
2. Health technologies and services
3. Valorisation and more effective use of local resources
4 Smart and sustainable solutions for energy
5. Viable Estonian society, language and culture
Objective(s): Horizontal support for research capacity and entrepreneurship.|Knowledge transfer and its mechanisms (e.g. increasing knowledge transfer capacity of the R&D institutions, building the ‘knowledge networks’ and business-academia links through the movement of employees between the academic, private and public sector; support for entrepreneurial PhD programmes; support for cooperation and co-creation between the academic, business and public sector within the national priority areas; strengthening the RD&I absorption capacity in the society and building RD&I-favourable policy environment through the network of research and development advisors in the public sector and in the private sector’s associations, and other activities).
Background: RDIE focus areas are research and innovation and business priority areas that offer solutions for Estonian development needs and opportunities in co-designed actions by the state, business sector and research institutions. Four focus areas (1-4) have an economic dimension and are therefore defined as the national smart specialisation areas. RDIE focus areas (including four smart specialisation areas) are integral part of RDIE Strategy and Estonian RDI system and thus subject to RDIE governance. Each focus area will have a road-map, including targets and critical key-actions. Co-design and co-creation (entrepreneurial discovery process) with respective stakeholders and monitoring on a yearly bases is essential part of the RDIE focus areas and activities within these focus areas. Activities within the RDIE focus areas involve RDI missions as tool for increased directionality for the entrepreneurial discovery process.

English name: GENERAL DIRECTORATE OF AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH AND POLICIES
Original name(s): TARIMSAL ARAŞTIRMALAR VE POLİTİKALAR GENEL MÜDÜRLÜĞÜ
Description: There are 49 research institutes affiliated to TAGEM throughout the country, including central, regional and subject-based institutes.
Objective(s): To make effort to enhance the capacity of R&D in agricultural technologies|To encourage the participation of academicians and researchers in related scientific fields in research activities|To improve research database and to monitor and evaluate the projects regularly|To transfer the results of the R&D to the users|To provide economic, social and environmental benefits to Turkey through concluding high quality agricultural R&D that meets the country needs
Background:
The Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry provides non-refundable direct payment support to R&D projects for the purpose of improving the knowledge and technologies that agricultural sector needs, transferring these knowledge and technologies to the farmers, agricultural industrialists and exporters and increasing the R&D capacities of the organizations in agricultural sector.
The universities, non-governmental organization, vocational institutions, farmer’s organizations and R&D projects carried out by private sector are supported within the scope of Communiqué on the Procedures Applied in Supporting the Research and Development Projects issued subject to agricultural law no 5488.
The Ministry started R&D project supports in 2007 and the secretarial Tasks regarding the Project application, Project evaluation and monitoring of approved projects are performed by General Directorate of Agricultural Research and Policies (TAGEM).
The institutions and organizations wishing to benefit from R&D support offer their project proposals within the specified time. After the projects are approved by the Evaluation Board and Secretariat created under Communiqué the contracts are signed and the projects become effective subsequently.
Responsible organisation(s): MINISTRY OF AGRICULTURE AND FORESTRY- GENERAL DIRECTORATE OF AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH AND POLICIES (TAGEM;TARIMSAL ARAŞTIRMALAR VE POLİTİKALAR GENEL MÜDÜRLÜĞÜ)

Original name(s): Bekker NAWA - Program im. Mieczysława Bekkera
Description: Mobility programme for outgoing PhD students and scientists. The Programme is open to PhD students and scientists representing all fields and disciplines of science as well as artistic disciplines. There are also no restrictions regarding countries where the Host Institutions are located.
Objective(s): The aim of the Programme is to support the international mobility of PhD students, scientists and academic teachers in pursuit of scientific excellence by enabling them to conduct their research in renowned foreign institutions around the world.
Background:
It is set up to coordinate state activities driving the process of internationalization of Polish academic and research institutions: [a] support international mobility of students, academics and researchers; [b] support the process of internationalization of Polish HEIs and research institutions; [c] promote Polish science and higher education.

Research fellowships (3 to 24 months) shall allow scientists to stay in recognized research centres and to implement the Projects together with eminent foreign scientists and scientific teams as well as establish long-term relationship with foreign scientific teams. For young scientists, the Bekker Programme will be also an opportunity for postdoctoral fellowships while for PhD students it can be the part of their education.
Responsible organisation(s): National Agency for Academic Exchange (NAWA;Narodowa Agencja Wymiany Akademickiej)

Description: There are currently 31 IIS accredited by the ISCIII. Evaluation, accreditation and monitoring program of IIS:
Its competencies in evaluation, accreditation and monitoring of the IIS, the General Sub-Directorate for Assessment and Promotion of Research developed during 2019 the following activities:
a) IIS Technical Evaluation Guide, approved by Ministerial Decree of April 12, 2019, of the Minister of Science, Innovation and Universities. In force since April 16, 2019.
b) Setting up the system of indicators for annual monitoring of accredited IIS.
c) Institutional IT platform of the ISCIII for shared work with the IIS.
d) IIS Forum, established on November 20, 2019.
e) Procedures for accreditation, renewal of accreditation and authorization of significant changes, according to Royal Decree 279/2016, of June 24.

Description: Information system to broaden access to science and technology (S&T) knowledge resources by building a national open science environment for core S&T information and research including theses, reports, research data, and R&D information.

With the launch of this system, operations of the National Digital Science Library (NDSL), in operation since 2001 were consolidated under the ScienceOn.

English name: FUNDING PROGRAMME FOR EXCELLENT SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH "MARÍA DE GUZMAN"
Original name(s): Ayudas para el fomento de la investigación científica de excelencia: María de Guzmán
Description: A new funding call is being launched in 2021 for supporting Open Science digital infrastructures in the institutions of the National R&D System.
Objective(s): To enhance and favor research of excellence by promoting Open Science through the reinforcement of institutional infrastructures for storage, long term preservation, dissemination and management of scientific outcomes.
Background:
Projects will finance activities like technical training, quality increase, and interoperability strengthening of those institutional digital infrastructures necessary for Open Science: open access repositories, CRIS systems and institutional publication services.
The “María de Guzmán” funding programme was created in 2019, but no Open Science initiative was included among its goals. It used to fund the acquisition of commercial bibliographic references databases for the universities and public research centres of the National landscape. In 2021, as a consequence of the design process of the National Open Science strategy in Spain, the “María de Guzman” programme enlarged its scope to include support to the Open Science digital infrastructures.
Responsible organisation(s): Spanish Foundation for Science and Technology (FECYT;Fundación Española para la Ciencia y la Tecnología)

Background:
Challenge programmes:

3 Transforming Food Production
4 Transforming Construction

6 Industrial Decarbonisation

10 Transforming Foundation Industries.

English name: NEW TECHNOLOGIES IN THE FIELD OF ENERGY
Description: The main goal of this strategic program is to support the achievement of Poland's climate neutrality by implementing solutions increasing the country's energy security and increasing the competitiveness of the Polish economy.
Objective(s): Increase the overall energy mix of the country by 20-50% (compared to the level from 2020).
Background:
The strategic national and European goals in the Program will be achieved through the implementation of research and development tasks with high innovative potential and a high degree of technology advancement (TRL 8 - 9) in the following 6 technological areas:
T1. Solar energy;
T2. Onshore and offshore wind energy;
T3. Technologies for the production and use of hydrogen;
T4. Energy storage and energy and heat microgrids;
T5. Energy use of waste and heat from post-process gases;
T6. Energetic use of geothermal heat (geothermal).
Responsible organisation(s): National Centre For Research and Development (NCBR;Narodowe Centrum Badań i Rozwoju)

Description: Initiative aimed at supporting deep capacity building and funding for community-driven clean energy planning and renewable energy projects in remote Indigenous communities that will support the transition away from a reliance on diesel for heat and power.
Objective(s): Support remote Indigenous communities in developing and implementing ambitious plans to reduce diesel use for heat and power.

The initiative was designed based on 18 months of engagement with
rights holders, Indigenous organizations and stakeholders. The IODI is
delivered in collaboration with the Indigenous Clean Energy Social
Enterprise and the Pembina Institute. By working together with these
partners, the IODI not only supports the development of clean energy
projects but also bolsters Indigenous leadership in Canada's cleaner
future.

English name: NATIONAL PLAN FOR SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY AND INNOVATION 2030
Original name(s): Plan Nacional de Ciencia, Tecnología e Innovación 2030
Description: Elaboration of the policies, strategies and instruments that should guide the activities of generation of knowledge and development of technologies of the science, technology and innovation sector (STI) towards the goals and results demanded by the development path outlined for our country.
Objective(s): To guarantee the production of scientific-technological knowledge will be oriented towards the integration of the industrial network and the increase of its density, the sustainable use of natural assets and the conformation or the strengthening of its value chains, with a special focus on the systemic and synergistic development of dynamic competitive advantages in the direction of structural change.
Background:
The context for the formulation of the PNCTI is characterized by a highly precarious socio-economic reality. This situation is aggravated by the outbreak of the pandemic generated by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which added a new dimension of uncertainty to the global environmental and financial crises, increasing social and economic vulnerability in developing countries.

The STI sector was not immune to the effects of the socio-economic crisis of recent years, nor to the emergence of the pandemic. The indicators of the CTI system show a general deterioration. However, at the beginning of the current administration, actions aimed at its recovery were carried out, not only economically but also territorially and symbolically and culturally, reactivating the regional approach and giving its institutions a higher hierarchy. In the context of the pandemic, the sector has demonstrated its ability to respond to the demands of the health emergency.
Responsible organisation(s): Ministry of Science, Technology and Productive Innovation (MINCYT;Ministerio de Ciencia, Tecnología e Innovación Productiva)

English name: TAX INCENTIVES FOR INVESTMENT IN STI
Original name(s): Incentivos tributarios por inversión en CTeI
Description: This initiative is an incentive for the development of science, technology and innovation projects by companies in alliance with actors recognized by the Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation, granting investors and / or executors, deductions and tax discounts. Similarly, the initiative strengthens the infrastructure for research in recognized educational institutions and research and technological development centers, through exemption from VAT on the import of equipment and elements, and encourage the participation of personnel in science, technology and innovation projects through Non-Constitutive Income from Income and / or Occasional Profit.
Objective(s): To encourage investment in R + D + I and promote competitiveness in companies and the development of high-impact research for the country.|Deduction and Discount for investments in Science, Technology and Innovation projects and exemption from Value Added Tax for imports of equipment and items.|Certification of income not constituting income or occasional gain.|Tax credit for investments in Science, Technology and Innovation projects.|Donation for STI activities.|Tax incentives for linking doctors to the business sector.
Background:
Deduction and Discount for investments in Science, Technology and Innovation projects: Law 6 of 1992 created this instrument as a first approach to encourage private investment in scientific and technological research, under the supervision of the National Council of Science and Technology. These investments could be made by universities approved by other government entities, allowing a deduction of 100% of the investment up to a limit of 20% of the Taxable Liquid Income. Subsequently, Law 383 of 1997 increased this deduction to 125% of the investment and allowed donations to projects of this nature. Law 633 of 2000 included among the projects that can access the deduction, technological innovation projects and centers recognized by Colciencias. Law 1286 of 2009 creates the National Council of Tax Benefits in Science, Technology and Innovation CNBT chaired by Colciencias. Law 1450 of 2011 increased the value of the deduction to 175% of the value of the investment and increased the limit to 40% of the taxable net income, in the same way it delegated to Colciencias the function of recognizing the actors that will accompany the project application process and eliminated innovation projects from the deduction. Law 1739 of 2014 again included innovation projects in the tax benefits package. Finally, law 1819 of 2016 modified the structure of the tax benefit allowing investments in science, technology and innovation projects to be deducted in the year in which it is made and deduct 25% of said investment directly from the tax to be paid, with a limit of 25% of the tax to be paid.

Exemption from Value Added Tax for the importation of equipment and elements: Law 6 of 1992 created an incentive for equipment and elements imported by higher education institutions, research centers and higher studies, duly recognized and intended for scientific or technological research projects and approved by the National Planning Department , shall enjoy exemption from sales tax. Subsequently, Law 633 of 2000 included as part of the entities that can access this exemption the Research Centers and Technological Development Centers recognized by Colciencias and delegated to Colciencias the function of qualifying the projects that can access tax benefits. Finally, Law 1450 of 2011 extended the scope of application of the instrument to educational institutions certified by the Ministry of National Education and delegated the qualification of projects to the National Council for Tax Benefits in Science, Technology and Innovation.

Income Not Constituting Income or Occasional Gain: Law 1450 of 2011 created a new tax benefit for the resources received by the taxpayer to be destined to the development of projects qualified as scientific, technological or innovation, according to the criteria and conditions defined by the National Council of Tax Benefits in Science, Technology and Innovation and for the remuneration of natural persons for the direct execution of scientific, technological or innovation tasks, provided that such remuneration comes from the resources destined to the respective project, according to the criteria and conditions defined by the National Council of Tax Benefits in Science, Technology and Innovation , resources that are declared as Income not constituting income or occasional gain.

Exempt Income: This tax benefit was in force until 2017, and consisted of the sales of the new software of high content of scientific research, Technological Development certified by Colciencias were considered exempt incomes. To date the tax benefit is Not In Force.

Donation to the Francisco José de Caldas Fund for CTeI projects: Approved by law 1955 of 2019, the Francisco José de Caldas Fund was allowed to receive donations that will obtain the tax benefit of the deduction of 100% of the money donated and the discount of 25%, and will be destined for CTeI projects. Between 2011 and 2016, donation is allowed for projects qualified by the CNBT for research centers and universities to seek funds.

Linking Doctors to Companies: This tax incentive was created by law 1955 of 2019, in order to create a support scheme for the linking of personnel with doctoral degrees through tax incentives for the development of R&D&I projects.

Tax Credit for Investments in R&D&I: This tax incentive was created by law 1955 of 2019, and seeks to create the figure of tax credit for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, seeking to expand the scope of the benefit of deduction and discount in R&D&I projects. The tax credit can resemble an unlimited tax discount, for the payment of income tax, compensation of national taxes and Investment Titles and Tax Refund TIDI.
Responsible organisation(s): Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation (MINCIENCIAS;Ministerio de Ciencia, Tecnología e Innovación)

Description: Acknowledgment and closing of capacity gaps in STI.
Objective(s): Structuring of guidelines, advice and technical support for the recognition of capacities in science, technology and innovation of the Actors of the National System of Science, Technology and Innovation – SNCTI.|Definition of guidelines and accompaniment for the development of the Model of measurement of research groups, technological development or innovation and recognition of researchers of the National System of Science, Technology and Innovation.|Definition of guidelines and accompaniment for the development of the Sciometric Model for the Indexation of Specialized National Scientific Journals - PUBLINDEX|Promote, accompany and grant acknowledgment to the capacities in science, technology and innovation activities of different actors of the National System of Science, Technology and Innovation - SNCTI.
Background:
"Guidance on the role and activities of STINS actors has historically been linked to recognition processes that have had as their main purpose the possibility of giving actors the oportunity of competing for public resources. The first related experiment, which sought to estimate the size of the country's scientific population and introduce order into the National System, took place in 1991 through a call for science and technology groups in which a total of 160 groups participated, of which Colciencias considered 134 groups as such.
From there, the idea of identifying the "reference groups" that would have priority for the National Science, Technology and Innovation Policy Document No. 1602 resource allocation arose. This call process was repeated in 1996, when the first definition of a research group was proposed, and later in 1997 and 1998.
As a result of Law 633 on Tax Reform of 2000 and in order to regulate the recognition of other actors, Colciencias published Resolution 0084 of 2001, which introduced the definitions of research center, research group and technological development center. For these actors, two modalities of recognition were established, namely: "automatic" for those who had already been evaluated within the framework of calls of the entity or who were active, and the "express" for groups and centers that conformed to the indicators that Colciencias would define. According to the Resolution, recognition was granted for a period of two years.
These provisions would be derogated eight years later by Resolution 504 of 2010, which established new definitions for research centres, technological development centres and scientific and technological research groups, as well as the requirements for the recognition of the first two. On that occasion, for the purposes of recognition, which would be valid for three years after being notified, there was a differentiation for the first time between autonomous and dependent centres.
Two years later, Resolution 688 of 2012, currently in force, redefined research centers and technological development centers, including in the latter the centers that develop programs for the dissemination, appropriation and use of science and technology. The recognition process was established as an open service with cut-off dates and would be effective for a period of three years.
In order to guarantee systematicity in the process of recognition of actors, Colciencias issues public policy guidelines for STINS actors in 2016. Since the issuance of this policy, the technical guides that define the requirements and characteristics to access the recognition have been improved. The guidelines issued in 2016 are currently being updated."

Objective(s): Structuring of guidelines, advice and technical support for the recognition of capacities in science, technology and innovation of the Actors of the National System of Science, Technology and Innovation – SNCTI.|Definition of guidelines and accompaniment for the development of the Model of measurement of research groups, technological development or innovation and recognition of researchers of the National System of Science, Technology and Innovation.|Definition of guidelines and accompaniment for the development of the Sciometric Model for the Indexation of Specialized National Scientific Journals - PUBLINDEX|Promote, accompany and grant acknowledgment to the capacities in science, technology and innovation activities of different actors of the National System of Science, Technology and Innovation - SNCTI.
Background:
"Guidance on the role and activities of STINS actors has historically been linked to recognition processes that have had as their main purpose the possibility of giving actors the oportunity of competing for public resources. The first related experiment, which sought to estimate the size of the country's scientific population and introduce order into the National System, took place in 1991 through a call for science and technology groups in which a total of 160 groups participated, of which Colciencias considered 134 groups as such.
From there, the idea of identifying the "reference groups" that would have priority for the National Science, Technology and Innovation Policy Document No. 1602 resource allocation arose. This call process was repeated in 1996, when the first definition of a research group was proposed, and later in 1997 and 1998.
As a result of Law 633 on Tax Reform of 2000 and in order to regulate the recognition of other actors, Colciencias published Resolution 0084 of 2001, which introduced the definitions of research center, research group and technological development center. For these actors, two modalities of recognition were established, namely: "automatic" for those who had already been evaluated within the framework of calls of the entity or who were active, and the "express" for groups and centers that conformed to the indicators that Colciencias would define. According to the Resolution, recognition was granted for a period of two years.
These provisions would be derogated eight years later by Resolution 504 of 2010, which established new definitions for research centres, technological development centres and scientific and technological research groups, as well as the requirements for the recognition of the first two. On that occasion, for the purposes of recognition, which would be valid for three years after being notified, there was a differentiation for the first time between autonomous and dependent centres.
Two years later, Resolution 688 of 2012, currently in force, redefined research centers and technological development centers, including in the latter the centers that develop programs for the dissemination, appropriation and use of science and technology. The recognition process was established as an open service with cut-off dates and would be effective for a period of three years.
In order to guarantee systematicity in the process of recognition of actors, Colciencias issues public policy guidelines for STINS actors in 2016. Since the issuance of this policy, the technical guides that define the requirements and characteristics to access the recognition have been improved. The guidelines issued in 2016 are currently being updated."
Responsible organisation(s): Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation (MINCIENCIAS;Ministerio de Ciencia, Tecnología e Innovación)

The EU-CELAC Working Group on Research Infrastructures (WG RI) was officially created in March 2017, highlighting the importance of Research Infrastructures (RI) as one of three strategic pillars of the EU-CELAC Common Research Area (CRA).
The mandate is clear: “to support policy coordination and the exchange of information to mobilise and strengthen RI cooperation between both regions, contributing to solve the global challenges while facilitating researchers’ mobility and the international access of RI”.
Co-chaired by the European Commission and Uruguay
Composed by representatives of the EU and LAC Ministers
EU Member States represented by national delegates: Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Czech Republic, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Spain, Sweden, United Kingdom.
In Latin America and the Caribbean currently 19 countries are members of the Working Group: Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, Paraguay, Panama, Peru, Dominican Republic, Uruguay and Venezuela
Meets at least once a year to decide future steps

Description: The FBIP addresses the generation, mobilization and integration of foundational biodiversity knowledge and information so that it can be managed and disseminated for addressing societal needs. The Programme is fully aligned to international and national obligations and objectives including the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD), the Intergovernmental Platform on Biodiversity & Ecosystem Services (IPBES), National Biodiversity Act, the National Biodiversity Strategy & Action Plan, the Global Change and Bio-economy Grand Challenges of DSIand its programme on Indigenous Knowledge Systems.

Description: Funding Programme for a total of 10 projects/consortia will be funded. Each project will be provided a max of R750 000 for over 36 months to be paid in annual instamment of R250 000 per annum per project.
Objective(s): The NRF will support all interdisciplinary research projects focused on the five challenges of this call, i.e. 1) Reducing inequalities and vulnerabilities|2) Building a more resilient and sustainable society|3) Fostering democratic governance and political participation|4) Advancing responsible and inclusive digital innovation|5) Ensuring effective and accurate communication and media
Background: Research-related costs: Activities to be supported may include expenses relating to field work such as conducting interviews / surveys / laboratory experiments, research-related trips, small equipment (consumables), etc. Airfare, accommodation, ground transport and subsistence should be calculated using rates as stipulated in institutional travel policies. Exchange programmes: To support short-term mobility or travel expenses (i.e. transport and accommodation costs) of the research team between the partnering countries. Doctoral research placements: The placements should enable the postgraduate students within the project to learn valuable new skills or techniques; access facilities or resources not readily available at home; build relationships with potential new collaborators; and advance complementary collaborative research. The duration of each placement is expected to be 3-6 months with flexibility to split the placement into several shorter visits. Longer placements may be undertaken where this would add value and these should be justified within the application. Placements must enhance, not replace, the standard training and study support that the postgraduate students receive. These placements must be managed to fit within the original funded period of the studentship. Additional funding will not be made available through this Call to support studentship extensions for those undertaking international placements. Applicants should include information about how these exchanges will be managed within their proposal. Knowledge sharing costs: In support of activities organised by the partners, such as joint workshops, seminars, conferences, symposia, lecture presentations, capacity building sessions, meetings, local/regional dissemination of results aimed at involving stakeholders, and/or end-users from outside the consortium. Airfare, accommodation, ground transport and subsistence should be calculated using rates as stipulated in institutional travel policies. Joint T-AP COVID-19 RRR Conferences: It’s mandatory for researchers to make budgetary provisions (travel and accommodation) to participate at conferences organised by the T-AP COVID-19 RRR Funders as part of the reporting requirements.

English name: AGRICULTURAL INNOVATION PROJECTS OF PUBLIC INTEREST
Original name(s): Proyectos de Innovación Agraria de Interés Público (PYT)
Description: Support funds for the implementation of innovation initiatives in the national forestry sector and the associated agri-food chain.
Objective(s): To promote an innovative sector provide financial incentives to third parties, for the development and implementation of initiatives and / or innovative solutions that seek to solve problems or take opportunities associated with the strategic challenges of FIA, linked to the national forestry sector and / or the associated agri-food chain. These obstacles must be common and transversal for at least a subset of companies and / or producers in the sector.
Background:
In the context of institutional modernization processes, promoted by the Ministry of Agriculture, during the last four months of 2018, FIA undertook a strategic planning process that incorporated the vision from the macro-zones, the different FIA units, and various users. This exercise confirmed that there are several different practices carried out by the other agencies that the FIA can incorporate or from which it can learn to improve its own operating processes.
An exhaustive review of the institution was necessary, including how the institution is framed in the process of reform of the National Innovation System - given the creation of the Ministry of Science, Technology, Knowledge and Innovation - as well as a review of the institutional objectives and how the instruments respond to the new challenges of the industry. Taking the technically contested evaluation as a reference, we reviewed how FIA is meeting users' needs, how it interacts with them, and how the institutional mission responds to these challenges.
FIA provides added value in the service it provides to users (e.g. providing feedback during the development of the innovation project), which was considered a difference compared to other public institutions within the NIS. Finally, the users considered barriers regarding the application forms for the instruments, since SMEs and cooperatives compete on equal terms with large research centers and universities, where the capacities to formulate projects are different. Users also pointed out that FIA’s information is difficult to access, in addition to the need to generate networks with the ecosystem and among themselves.
All of the above has repercussions on a new approach for how FIA interacts with its beneficiaries: potentially innovative firms in the forestry and agricultural sector and/or in the associated agri-food chain. Concerning the new way of approaching public instruments, it is worth highlighting a series of considerations along with the transversal axes and the strategic challenges described above:
 The financing instrument requires specifying whether it aims to finance private goods (innovation projects executed by firms) or public goods (generation of non-appropriable goods or services, by any actor in the National Innovation System).
 Also, the project to be financed has to be adapted to the needs and the life stage of the project, understanding that both the innovation projects of private goods, as well as the public goods that enable innovation are heterogeneous in various dimensions. For example, there is no common pattern regarding technological intensity, scale, whether it is scientifically based or not, or whether it is a radical or incremental innovation.
This is especially important in the final stages of the project, particularly around the implementation and commercialization of the innovation. In the review process of the instruments by LIP, the lack of support instruments for this phase was underscored, not only those from FIA, but from all the public instruments.
 To ensure the successful closure of the projects, a support tool is also created in the implementation phase of the innovation, called “consolidation” of the project. At this stage, efforts will be made to adapt public support according to the specific needs of the beneficiary and the project in particular: financing, creation and / or strengthening of the capacities necessary to market (e.g. establish contacts with the distribution chain or advice to manage the business plan). FIA will provide support at two different levels, according to the project: connection with other FIA instruments (such as consultancies or events), or connection with other actors of the National Innovation System (such as business incubators).

 However, it is understood that the user's "journey" to develop innovation projects (or an innovation enabler in the case of public goods) is not uniform. From Figure 17 it can be seen that there are 7 different ways to finance a project: according to the type of asset to be financed, and according to the activities and the phase in which the innovative project is.
Responsible organisation(s): Foundation for Agricultural Innovation (FIA;Fundación para la Innovación Agraria)
Theme area(s): Innovation in firms and innovative entrepreneurship|Public research system
Theme(s): Competitive research funding|Financial support to business R&D and innovation
Target group type(s): Firms by age|Firms by size|Intermediaries|Research and education organisations
Target group(s): Academic societies / academies|Firms of any age|Firms of any size|Higher education institutes|Industry associations|Private research and development lab|Technology transfer offices
Policy instrument type: Procurement programmes for R&D and innovation

 Also, the project to be financed has to be adapted to the needs and the life stage of the project, understanding that both the innovation projects of private goods, as well as the public goods that enable innovation are heterogeneous in various dimensions. For example, there is no common pattern regarding technological intensity, scale, whether it is scientifically based or not, or whether it is a radical or incremental innovation.
This is especially important in the final stages of the project, particularly around the implementation and commercialization of the innovation. In the review process of the instruments by LIP, the lack of support instruments for this phase was underscored, not only those from FIA, but from all the public instruments.
 To ensure the successful closure of the projects, a support tool is also created in the implementation phase of the innovation, called “consolidation” of the project. At this stage, efforts will be made to adapt public support according to the specific needs of the beneficiary and the project in particular: financing, creation and / or strengthening of the capacities necessary to market (e.g. establish contacts with the distribution chain or advice to manage the business plan). FIA will provide support at two different levels, according to the project: connection with other FIA instruments (such as consultancies or events), or connection with other actors of the National Innovation System (such as business incubators).

 However, it is understood that the user's "journey" to develop innovation projects (or an innovation enabler in the case of public goods) is not uniform. From Figure 17 it can be seen that there are 7 different ways to finance a project: according to the type of asset to be financed, and according to the activities and the phase in which the innovative project is.

Original name(s): Zvanični proizvođač statistike za istraživanje i razvoj u Crnoj Gori
Description: As the official producer of statistical research and development (R&D) in Montenegro, Ministry of Education, Science, Culture and Sports collects data that provide all mandatory indicators with breakdowns defined in the EU Commission Implementing Regulation for statistics on science and technology (995/2012), in line with the methodological guidelines defined in the Guidelines for collecting and reporting data on research and experimental development.
Objective(s): R&D statistics provide internationally comparable data on total R&D spending and R&D staff.
Background:
As the official producer of research and development (R&D) statistics in Montenegro, the Ministry of Education, Science, Culture and Sports is publishing key R&D statistics for 2019. The data collected provide all mandatory indicators with breakdowns defined in the EU Commission Implementing Regulation for statistics on science and technology (995/2012), in line with the methodological guidelines defined in the Guidelines for collecting and reporting data on research and experimental development (Frascati Manual, OECD, 2015). Data are produced within 18 months following the end of the year observed, and are published nationally and submitted to Eurostat.

R&D statistics provide internationally comparable data on total R&D spending and R&D staff. Data are collected from reporting units – entities conducting R&D activities based on their financial and staff records. Data have been collected from units within four sectors of implementation: higher education, government, business-entrepreneurial and private nonprofit sector.

The results of the survey for 2019 indicate that total domestic spending on research and development in 2019 amounted to 0.36% of GDP, i.e. gross expenditures for R&D amounted to EUR 17,984,722. In 2019, 2330 persons were engaged in research and development activities in organisations, institutions and companies active in this field, including 1586 researchers, 495 technicians and 249 supporting staff members.

Given that R&D activities represent only part of the work engagement of most employees, actual engagement is shown through the full-time equivalent, which is the ratio of hours devoted by one employee to R&D and the total number of working hours. In 2019, total FTE was 685, and FTE for researchers was 469.
Responsible organisation(s): Ministry of Education, Science, Culture and Sports (MESCS;Ministarstvo prosvjete, nauke, kulture i sporta)

English name: GRANTS TO ENCOURAGE PARTICIPATION IN HORIZON AND COST PROGRAMMES
Description: Grants to encourage participation in Horizon and COST programmes are aimed at increasing participation of Montenegrin institutions in Horizon 2020 and COST, as well as other international research and innovation programmes.
Objective(s): The increased participation of Montenegrin institutions in Horizon 2020 and COST, as well as other international research and innovation programmes.
Background:
Call for proposals published in 2017 and 2019, respectively. The main goal of the Call for proposals is to increase participation in Horizon 2020 and COST, as well as other international research and innovation programmes. The Call for proposals is focused on expanding research and innovation networks and contacts through new partnerships, as well as on launching such research at the national level that is the same or similar to the research conducted in the EU. A project planned to be implemented in Montenegro could have such activities that are same or similar (on a smaller scale) to those implemented by a consortium of European partners through the ongoing H2020 project, in which the Montenegrin team would have the status of an observer or third party. In this way, it would be possible to catch up with advanced European research, exercise close communication and cooperation with European partners and facilitate future involvement in larger-scale, EU calls for applications.

The main criteria for evaluating the projects under this Call for proposals are: implementation and feasibility; the quality of the research team; involvement of young researchers and professional associates; and the impact of the project on strengthening the scientific research or innovation team, institution and state in the selected research / innovation area.

The total budget of the Ministry earmarked under the Call for proposals amounts to EUR 200,000.

English name: SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY PARK OF MONTENEGRO
Description: Science and Technology Park of Montenegro (STP) is a priority infrastructure project of the Government of Montenegro.
Objective(s): The STP was established with a view to integrating and stimulating innovative, scientific, entrepreneurial and economic capacities in Montenegro, and will be directly involved in the implementation of certain measures and instruments of support to the academic and business community defined by the S3 Strategy, with the mission of strengthening the links between the business sector and the scientific and academic community and creating innovative start-ups.
Background:
The Science and Technology Park Montenegro was established in partnership of Government of Montenegro, former Ministry of Science and University of Montenegro with a common vision to become a key place where innovative and creative individuals and projects will merge, along with the intensive cooperation of key stakeholders of entrepreneurial process (science and economy). With its position, located within the campus, University of Montenegro as well as administrative and business centre of the capital, Science and Technology Park Montenegro will offer more than adequate conditions for small business development, for stimulating the development of start-ups, creating creative and innovative teams of multidisciplinary orientation.

The STP will be facilitated in a building of about 14,000 square meters. For this purpose, a complete project for the reconstruction and adaptation has already been done.

The STP is currently in the phase of conceiving its activities and developing guidelines for the implementation of future steps aimed at achieving its mission and vision. STP is mapping and establishing cooperation and communication with key stakeholders of the innovation-entrepreneurial ecosystem in Montenegro and the region.
Responsible organisation(s): Ministry of Economic Development (MED;Ministarstvo ekonomskog razvoja)

Description: Colombia’s Center for Digital Public Innovation is an initiative of the MinTIC that works with innovation methods that stimulate the use of digital technologies to promote the State's digital transformation. It works as: laboratory, providing tailor-made support to solve challenges by applying emerging technologies; knowledge agency, coordinating capsules and events on digital innovation, and as a catalyst for the ecosystem, through projects and spaces that connect ecosystem actors.
Objective(s): To promote the implementation of digital government policy in public entities.|To stimulate the public innovation ecosystem and be the most excellent promoter of its digital dimension.
Background:
The Center for Digital Public Innovation (CIPD), originally called the Center for Innovation in Electronic Government, was born in 2013 as part of the Online Government Directorate, within the framework of an inter-institutional project between the Ministry of Information Technologies and the Communications ─MinTIC─, the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs ─UNDESA─ and the United Nations Development Program ─PNUD.

The CIDP's purpose was to strengthen the innovation capacity of public entities, making use of ICT as a tool. Consequently, for the Center, three pillars have been identified on which its management rests:
• Strengthening capacities to innovate.
• Increasing connections between ecosystem actors and their diversity.
• Fostering an environment prone to innovation.

Description:
Set up by French space agency CNES and ArianeGroup, ArianeWorks is an innovation-boosting acceleration platform for future launcher development.

Its main mission is to speed up implementation of the Themis programme, the low-cost, reusable first stage demonstrator.
Objective(s):
Accelerate the innovation process, in order to prepare for future developments of Ariane.

ArianeWorks aims to reduce the time between the formulation of an idea and its realisation. Teams work together in a highly flexible environment, using an iterative design/testing approach.

The first project of ArianeWorks is called Themis. It is a multi-purpose, low-cost, reusable first stage rocket demonstrator. It has two main objectives: halve the cost of launches and greatly reduce their environmental impact. In the longer term, ArianeWorks intends to use its New Space-inspired innovation methods for other missions.|Inspire and involve new players, such as pioneering start-ups, laboratories, SMEs and manufacturers.

ArianeWorks accelerates innovation at grassroots level, with cost reduction as a key priority. ArianeWorks also acts as a pathfinder, ables to accurately assess the technological context in order to make the right choices within the shortest timescales. This calls for an approach resolutely geared towards open innovation, to encourage the exchange of expertise and spawn a ground-breaking new ecosystem.
Responsible organisation(s): National Centre for Space Studies (CNES;Centre national d'études spatiales)|ArianeGroup (;ArianeGroup)

English name: PERTE FOR RENEWABLES ENERGIES, RENEWABLE HYDROGEN AND STORAGE
Original name(s): PERTE de energías renovables, hidrógeno renovable y almacenamiento
Description: Strategic Project for the Recovery and Economic Transformation (PERTE in Spanish) of Renewable Energies, Renewable Hydrogen and Storage. The government is allocating EUR 6.9 billion to innovative green energy technologies, expecting that the money would further mobilise close to EUR 9.5 billion from the private sector. Of the total sum, EUR 1.56 billion will go towards the development of renewable hydrogen projects.
Objective(s): To boost R&D and the value chain associated to hydrogen technologies: for new test or manufacturing lines for hydrogen components, for prototypes of new hydrogen-powered vehicles or demonstrators of large electrolysers to produce renewable hydrogen on a large scale.|To boost R&D projects in the field of energy storage.|To promote pilot projects for energy communities that are linked to social innovation and citizen participation in the generation of renewables, energy efficiency or electric mobility.
Background: Most of the amount will be awarded between 2022 and 2023, while the projects will be executed by 2026.
Responsible organisation(s): Ministry of Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge (MITECO;Ministerio para la Transición Ecológica y el Reto Demográfico )

Theme(s): Competitive research funding|Financial support to business R&D and innovation|Green energy transitions

Original name(s): Facilitating macro-regional scope and link up to socio-economic actors of Research Infrastructure in the Danube Region
Description: ResInfra @DR focused on research infrastructures in the Danube macro‐region and it offered mutual learning opportunities for policy makers and the policy delivery organisations involved in the financing, and parent organisations arranging the operation of research infrastructures.
Objective(s): The project mission was to improve framework conditions for research infrastructure and innovation in the Danube region. ResInfra@DR facilitated enhanced transnational cooperation and a macro-regional scope of the sustainable development of research infrastructures.
Background:
In view of ever more complex and differentiated innovation and research funding mix in the Danube macro‐region, coupled with the current circumstances of financial crisis that highly affects the public sector investments, the absence of adequate ex‐ante review, monitoring and impact oriented assessments on Science, Techn ology and Innovation (STI) programmes and specifically on research infrastructures (RI), is a serious bottleneck for the entire STI funding system and the innovation management cycle.

Evidence based policy making and successful RI investments require strategic tools and guidelines to enhance socio‐economic impact: ResInfra@DR ai ms to contribute to the efforts both to establish new research infrastructures as well as to requested processes for the upgrading of the existing RIs and to reassess their functionality i.a. by the development of methodologies which adequately reflect the specific situation in the Danube macro‐region.

Moreover, efforts to ease the utilization of RIs on regional level are necessary to prove the usefulness of proper public funding in research and development (R&D). ResInfra@DR links socio‐economic actors of RI in the Danube macro‐region by improving the framework conditions for innovation and stimulates the private actors to co‐fund in future RI investments i.e. in private public partnerships.
Responsible organisation(s): Ministry of Education and Science (MES;Ministry of Education and Science)

English name: CRITICAL MINERALS RESEARCH PROGRAM REQUEST FOR INFORMATION
Description: USD675 million grant program funded by the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act. This Request for Information (RFI) issued by the Department of Energy solicits feedback from industry, academia, research laboratories, government agencies, state and local coalitions, labor unions, tribes, community-based organizations, and others, on the structure of the program, timing and distribution of funds, and selection criteria.
Objective(s): To address vulnerabilities in the domestic critical minerals supply chain.|Specifically, the program will develop materials, components and technologies, promote efficient production and use, circular economy approaches, and ensure a long-term, diverse, secure, and sustainable supply of critical materials.
